Title: Filming The Field 1989
Description:
Jim Sheridans film production of John B Keanes play The Field is underway in the Connemara Village of Leenane. The Village of Leenane on the borderline of Galway and Mayo in North Connemara is the location for the 3 million film production of The Field, John B Keanes powerful drama of land hunger and rural passions. The Field featured in the film is located between Leenane and Westport. Noel Gaynors pub will feature heavily in the film and has been transformed back to the 1940s. Filming is expected to continue for two months and world famous actors Richard Harris, John Hurt, Tom Berenger and Brenda Fricker head up the cast. Locals are delighted the film production has chosen to come to Leenane with many of them are involved in the film.

Title: Life As A Breadman, Dublin City, Ireland 1981
Description:
Leo Mahon shares tales from his 56 years delivering bread for Johnston Mooney & OBrien.

When Leo Mahon started work on 24 June 1924 at the age of 14 bread was delivered by a horse drawn van.

Work was tough on the horses during the winter months especially along the Merrion Road to Booterstown with the east wind in their faces. However, the summer months made up for it.

Leo Mahon started out as an assistant to the van driver by the name of Mr Pat Owens, who had previously worked for the company known as Kavanaghs of College Street.

Title: Electricity Comes To Rural Ireland in 1946
Description:
On 5 November 1946, the Electricity Supply Board (ESB) embarked on the Rural Electrification Scheme to bring electricity to rural and remote areas of Ireland.

The scheme, known as The Quiet Revolution brought huge socio-economic change affecting the working, social and domestic lives of people all over Ireland. The first electricity pole was erected on 5 November 1946 at Kilsallaghan in North County Dublin with the first lights being switched on at Oldtown, also in North Dublin.

Title: The Evolution of DART: Inside the Central Control Room, Ireland 1986
Description:
Explore the advanced centralised traffic control system at Connolly Station that revolutionized the Dublin Area Rapid Transit (DART) rail service. When launched in 1984, DART was controlled by 16 signal cabins, but now the entire system is monitored from a central control room at Connolly Station.

Chief inspector Brendan Barnes highlights the numerous advantages of a computer-based signaling system over the old manual system, emphasizing its enhanced safety. Signalman Tony Reynolds shares his experience transitioning from a manual signal box to the computerized system after a fourteen-week training course.

Gerry Hunt, another signalman, demonstrates how he ensures level crossings are clear by monitoring screens and pressing buttons on the console. He recounts various incidents and the occasional need for coordination among signalmen during crossing issues.

Despite the technological advancements, Reynolds nostalgically recalls the days of manual signaling, where he could directly observe the passing trains. This episode of Visual Eyes aired on 2 July 1986, presented by Dave Fanning.

Title: The Historical Origins of Halloween (Oche Shamhna) in Ireland, 1995
Description:
Discover the rich history of Halloween (Oche Shamhna) in Ireland with Dr. Bairbre N Fhloinn of the National Folklore Collection in UCD. This episode answers viewers' questions about Halloween, explaining how it combines pre-Christian and Christian customs and traditions.

Learn about the origins of Halloween, which date back to the pagan festival of Samhain, later absorbed into the Christian calendar as All Hallows Eve, the night before All Saints Day on 1 November. The day after, 2 November, is All Souls Day, making Halloween truly a 'festival of the dead'.

Viewers from across Ireland share their memories and questions, such as what foods were traditionally eaten at Halloween, with apples and nuts being particularly popular. Discover traditional Halloween games like trying to bite an apple tied to a string without using hands, a game enjoyed in both urban and rural areas.

This episode of Echo Island was broadcast on 30 October 1995 and presented by Blthnaid N Chofaigh and Dara  Briain. Echo Island was a popular Irish television program for young people on RT Network 2, featuring segments on crafts, pet care, interviews, book and film reviews, and music. It ran for six seasons from 1994 to 1999, with a dynamic lineup of presenters including Dara  Briain, Blthnaid N Chofaigh, Alan Hughes, Derek Mooney, Mary Kingston, and Carrie Crowley.

Title: Pagan and Christian Roots of Halloween, 1991
Description:
Delve into the fascinating origins of Halloween with Father Sen  Dinn as he explains the pagan roots and Christian influences of this ancient festival. Dr. Sen  Dinn OSB, a Benedictine monk at Glenstal Abbey and a renowned Celtic scholar, discusses how the pre-Christian festival of Samhain was integrated into the Christian calendar, becoming All Hallows Eve. This episode explores the significance of Halloween in the Celtic calendar, its associated traditions, and the beliefs surrounding this mystical night.

Learn about the traditional customs such as the barmbrack ring, where finding the ring signifies marriage within the year, and the practice of children going door-to-door in costumes, a modern take on offerings to the supernatural Tuatha D Danann. This episode of Would You Believe was broadcast on 31 October 1991 and is presented by Michael Ryan.

Description:
Once described as the prettiest village, residents of Chapelizod in Dublin now fear it is becoming a ghost town. In the past two years, forty-one families have left, and more are expected to follow. Issues such as underdevelopment, lack of housing, and bad roads plague the village. The Chapelizod Residents Association, led by Samus  Murch, has met with Dublin Corporation to address these grievances. Plans to widen the bridge threaten the demolition of a 300-yard stretch of houses, adding to residents' concerns. Despite these challenges, there is hope with the construction of new factory buildings. This RT News report, broadcast on 21 August 1962, is presented by Sean Egan.

Title: Heatwave in Leinster and Munster, 1998
Description:
Warm weather across Leinster and Munster offers a brief reprieve from one of the worst summers in decades. The Meteorological Office forecasts tropical winds and sunshine for much of the east, south, and southeast, predicting 8 August to be the hottest day of 1998. While most of Munster and Leinster enjoy temperatures in the high 20s Celsius, Ulster and Connacht are not as fortunate. Killiney beach in County Dublin is packed with sunbathers, and Kilkenny experiences a mini heatwave. Unfortunately, the spell of warm weather is short-lived, with cooler and wetter conditions expected soon. This RT News report, broadcast on 8 August 1998, is presented by Aileen OMeara.

Title: Retracing St. Brendan's Voyage: Dingle to Newfoundland, 1976
Description:
The leather-covered boat Brendan sets off on an ambitious voyage to retrace the route that Saint Brendan supposedly took to America in the sixth century. The RT News footage shows Tim Severin and his crew preparing to set sail, loading equipment and supplies on board the vessel on the Dingle peninsula. A crowd gathers on the shore to wish them well as the Brendan is escorted out of the harbour by smaller craft. The 36-foot currach, built in Crosshaven, will make a 4,000-mile journey to Newfoundland with its five-man crew, including George Maloney and Arthur Mangan. The boats frame is made of ash and oak, covered with ox-hide, and the sails are made of goat skin. This footage was broadcast as part of an RT News report on 17 May 1976.

Discover the invaluable service of the Mayo County mobile libraries, which cover up to 1000 miles per week, bringing 3000 books to rural communities. Operating on a fortnightly run with 93 stops, the mobile library serves farmers, priests, schoolchildren, and more. Library assistant Mary Glady shares her joy in meeting diverse customers, while County Librarian Pat McMahon emphasizes the library's role in self-education and community engagement.

An RT News report broadcast on 6 January 1981.

Title: Patty Hearst's Harrowing Ordeal: From Heiress to Captive, Ireland 1993
Description:
In a gripping interview, Patty Hearst recounts her abduction by the Symbionese Liberation Army (SLA) on February 4, 1974. As the granddaughter of American publishing magnate William Randolph Hearst, her kidnapping shocked the nation. Held captive in a closet for 60 days, Hearst was coerced into participating in criminal activities, including bank robbery.

Hearst was eventually captured by the FBI and sentenced to 35 years in prison, later reduced to seven. She claimed brainwashing and manipulation as her defense, and President Jimmy Carter commuted her sentence, leading to her release after three years.

Joined by her husband Bernard Shaw, Patty Hearst shares her harrowing experience on Kenny Live. She describes herself as a typical 19-year-old student at the University of California, uninvolved in politics. Hearst details the SLA's actions and their impact on her life, providing a chilling insight into her ordeal.

This episode of Kenny Live was broadcast on April 3, 1993, with Pat Kenny as the presenter.

Title: Countess Markievicz: A Revolutionary's Legacy, Ireland 2007
Description:
Explore the life and legacy of Countess Constance Markievicz through a captivating exhibition at Lissadell House in Sligo. Curated by Eddie Walsh and Constance Cassidy, this collection features invaluable memorabilia, including detailed plans of the 1916 Rising, personal artifacts, and artworks.

The exhibition showcases Markievicz's journey from her childhood at Lissadell to her pivotal role in the 1916 Rising. Highlights include her Fianna Fil membership card, poetry, sketches, and paintings created during her imprisonment in Holloway Jail. The display also features her wedding veil and portraits painted by her husband Casimir Markievicz.

An RT News report broadcast on March 30, 2007, provides a detailed look at this remarkable collection. The report is presented by Eileen Magnier.

Explore the unique charm of Levis pub in Ballydehob, County Cork, run by sisters Julia and Nell Levis. This quaint establishment, part pub, part shop, offers a cozy atmosphere where Julia Levis engages with customers, listens to their stories, and even handles the occasional rowdy patron with ease.

The pub comes alive in the evenings with entertainment provided by Martina Kelly on the accordion, all against a backdrop of grocery shelves. Levis pub is a beloved local spot where community and conversation thrive.

Title: File 92: Music and Memories from the 'Trip To Tipp' Festival, 1992
Description:
Relive the highlights of File 92, the three-day music festival in Thurles, County Tipperary. Liberty Square and Semple Stadium were packed with enthusiastic crowds enjoying performances by Luka Bloom, David Byrne, Bryan Adams, and The Saw Doctors.

Galway band The Saw Doctors, headlined by singer Leo Moran, describe the electric atmosphere at their concerts as a big singalong with fans. Many festival-goers camped out in nearby fields, creating a vibrant and communal festival experience.

This episode of Jo-Maxi was broadcast on September 28, 1992, with reporter Shauna Lowry capturing the event's energy and excitement.

Jo-Maxi was a youth lifestyle program on Network 2, covering topics like animals, fashion, music, and more. It originally aired on October 10, 1988, and continued until 1994 under the rebranded name JMTV.

Title: Discovering the Heart of Leitrim, Ireland 1981
Description:
Dive into the rich history and vibrant culture of Leitrim through the eyes of its residents.

This documentary, titled None But Devils, begins with the Bard of Breffni Contest at the Ballinamore Festival, a celebration started 23 years ago to uplift the town after losing its railway connection. The festival brings together locals and visitors for a week of festivities, including publicans obstacle races and rick tossing contests.

Join historian priest Fr. Dan Gallogly on a grand tour of Leitrim, showcasing scenic and historical sites. At Fenagh Abbey, meet stonemason Jim Joe McKiernan, who has spent his life restoring and preserving the cemetery's stonework. Jim Joe views the cemetery as an art gallery of his life's work, with his own marked plot as part of the exhibit.

None But Devils A Leitrim Documentary was broadcast on 29 July 1981, revealing Leitrim through the perspectives of a miner, a farmer, a civil servant, a dancer, a historian priest, and a monumental mason who dreams of playing the fiddle.

Title: The Ennis Pig Hunt, Co. Clare, Ireland 2003
Description:
A potentially dangerous Vietnamese pot-bellied pig is on the loose in Clare, causing havoc and fear among residents.

This week, ISPCA dog warden Frankie Coote in County Clare is on an unusual mission to locate a wild Vietnamese pot-bellied pig. Believed to be a former pet, the pig has been roaming a 1.5-mile stretch between Ennis and Barefield since 2002.

The pig, first seen in the Corrovorrin housing estate, has now become a menace. It has chased a woman going to work, frightened an elderly man, and disturbed farm animals, even putting 18 cattle out of their field.

To lure the pig out, recordings of piggery sounds are being used. Frankie Coote is concerned about the pigs potential threat to children and elderly people.

An RT News report broadcast on 8 August 2003. The reporter is Cathy Halloran.

Title: Music and Fun at Fleadh Cheoil Sligo, Ireland 1990
Description:
The traditional Irish music festival returns to Sligo, drawing thousands for a celebration of music and culture.

RT News covers Fleadh Cheoil na hireann in Sligo Town, where 110,000 music enthusiasts gather. Among them, 3,500 musicians compete in various categories, while the rest enjoy the music and the lively atmosphere.

Besides music events, the festival includes competitions promoting the Irish language and a hospitality committee catering to international visitors.

An RT News report from 26 August 1990. The reporter is Eileen Magnier.

Title: Remembering Liam Clancy of The Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem, Ireland 2009
Description:
A tribute to the life and career of singer, actor, and musician Liam Clancy of The Clancy Brothers & Tommy Makem.

Born in Carrick-on-Suir in 1935, Liam Clancy dreamed of a life on stage. He traveled to the United States, joining his brothers Paddy and Tom and performing with Tommy Makem. Their signature Aran jumpers, sent by Mrs. Clancy, became iconic as they played venues like the White Horse Tavern in New York.

Their appearance on The Ed Sullivan Show in 1961 catapulted them to international stardom, contributing significantly to the 1960s folk revival. Bob Dylan described Liam as 'the best ballad singer Id ever heard in my life.'

Liam pursued a successful solo career and reunited with Makem for 13 years. The quartet reunited in 1984 for a documentary and tours. Settling in An Rinn, County Waterford, Liam continued performing and published his autobiography The Mountain of the Women in 2002. A documentary film The Yellow Bittern was released in 2009.

An RT News report broadcast on 4 December 2009. The reporter is Sinad Crowley.

Title: Rounding Up Wild Bulls in Loughrea, Co. Galway, 2003
Description:
The gallivanting days are over for wild bulls roaming through East Galway.

It took nine days and 30 locals to round up and pen the nine bulls and 14 other cattle which have been causing havoc in east Galway for seven or eight years.

For years they raged out of control in the hills above Loughrea.

The runaway bulls belong to local farmer Martin Kelly, who admits he is unable to control them. Kilnadeema farmer Bob Callanan recalls the many dangers the bulls have posed to their cows over the years.

Officials from the Department of Agriculture did nothing to solve the matter, eventually deciding to bring in the army to shoot the animals. It was at this point that local people got together to stop this action from going ahead.

A local politician stood forward to take on the role of a latter-day sheriff.

Local councillor Michael Regan directed the volunteers involved with rounding up the wild bulls and other cattle. As well as helping with the roundup, local people also provided transportation to bring the animals to a nearby farmers slatted shed.

The herd of 25 bulls, cows, and calves has an estimated value of 25,000 euros. The intention now is to sell the herd, and Martin Kelly is happy to be compensated. He plans to start again with some tamer cattle.

An RT News report broadcast on 7 August 2003. The reporter is Jim Fahy.

Title: Carlow Residents Discuss TV Quiz Shows, 2000
Description:
What do the people of Carlow think about television quiz shows?

With programmes like Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? dominating the television schedules, actor and comedian Patrick McDonnell travels to Carlow to find out what people there think of quiz shows. 

Patrick McDonnell asks a number of unsuspecting locals some quickfire questions from the quiz show Quicksilver. This show, hosted by Bunny Carr, was broadcast on RT television from 1965 to 1981. 

One man fails to answer any of the geography-themed questions, and another man is unable to identify the sign of the zodiac for September,

'I wasnt born that month.'

When asked for her opinion on Quicksilver, an elderly woman is reluctant to comment,

'I dont like giving my opinion about Bunny Carr or any public character to the media.'

This clip includes a comedy sketch in which actor Paul Tylak plays Ranjith, a quiz show contestant in Pats Game Show, hosted by Patrick McDonnell.

Dont Feed the Gondolas was a celebrity comedy quiz show hosted by Sen Moncrieff for the first three series and Brendan OConnor for the fourth and final series. Contestants examined some of the more bizarre manifestations of the Irish and international media. The programme featured a number of Irish comedians, including Dara  Briain, Des Bishop, Eddie Bannon, Kevin McAleer, and Patrick McDonnell. The first episode was broadcast on 1 December 1997. Dont Feed the Gondolas ended on 26 March 2001.

This episode of Dont Feed the Gondolas was broadcast on 23 October 2000. The presenter is Brendan OConnor.

Title: Immigration's Impact on Ennis, Ireland 2001
Description:
A report from Ennis, Co. Clare, where over a thousand asylum seekers have settled in the last decade.

Ennis, known for its traditional culture, is undergoing a transformation with the arrival of many asylum seekers. The Refugee Council is collaborating with government departments to establish support systems for these new residents, including accommodation, financial aid, and language education to help them gain independence. Meanwhile, the Immigration Control Platform led by ine N Chonaill opposes immigration, calling it a charter for 'invasion.'

Dympna Moroney speaks to Eni Olaleye from Nigeria, Anto Christelle from Congo, and Annette Geuyen from the Netherlands about their experiences as immigrants in Ireland.

In addition to hearing from non-nationals, Dympna Moroney also meets three Traveller women who feel marginalized by the community.

Eamon Naughton of the Clare County Development Board discusses investment plans for Ennis over the next ten years. Dr. William Walsh, Bishop of Killaloe, advocates for treating all people with dignity and respect.

An RT News report broadcast on 8 August 2001. The reporter is Dympna Moroney.

Title: Traditional Music at Gus OConnors Pub, 1973
Description:
Irish traditional music from Gus OConnors Pub in Doolin, County Clare.

At the fireside of Gus OConnors Pub in Doolin, County Clare, Irish traditional musicians Packie Russell on the concertina and Marcus Walsh on bodhrn play the reels The Milliners Daughter and The First House in Connacht.

The Russell family from Doolin in County Clare are renowned musicians. Packie Russells brother Micho is famous for his tin whistle playing, and his brother Gussie is a flute and whistle player.

A miscellany of events, entertainment, opinions, and personalities, Tangents was first aired on Monday 25 September 1972 and ran until 1974. Tangents was presented by Cathal OShannon and Doireann N Bhriain on Monday, Wednesday, Thursday, and Friday and by John ODonoghue each Tuesday.

This episode of Tangents was broadcast on 16 April 1973.

Title: Fleadh Mr Music Festival at Tramore Racecourse, 1993
Description:
Fleadh Mr, a large-scale music festival, held at Tramore Racecourse in Waterford.

Fleadh Mr takes place on 3 and 4 July 1993 at Tramore Racecourse in County Waterford. Festival goers, each paying 25 a day for their tickets, have the opportunity to enjoy practically nonstop music from noon to midnight. The event is billed as,

The biggest music festival of its type ever staged in this country.

The festival line-up includes 67 acts performing on three stages, including Bob Dylan, Van Morrison, Ray Charles, Jimmy Cliff, and The Pogues. Also in the mix are Christy Moore, Nanci Griffith, Hothouse Flowers, Joan Baez, Jerry Lee Lewis, and Moving Hearts.

It meant a huge logistical and security operation, and Garda took some young people into custody to let the effects of drink wear off.

The event is run by the Mean Fiddler, the biggest music festival operator in the United Kingdom, founded by Waterford man Vince Power.

Attending the Fleadh Mr are newlyweds Paul Hill of the Guilford Four and his wife Courtney Kennedy, daughter of the late Senator Robert Kennedy, who are honeymooning in Ireland. Both are huge fans of Irish music.

An RT News report broadcast on 4 July 1993. The reporter is Michael Ryan.

Title: The Historical Seaside Town of Ardmore, Co. Waterford, 1979
Description:
A visit to the seaside town of Ardmore in County Waterford, believed to be the oldest Christian settlement in Ireland.

The small town of Ardmore on the border of Cork and Waterford has a winter population of 400 or 500, but during the summer months, the town is thronged with tourists from all over Ireland. During the winter, fishing is Ardmores main industry.

Children from a local school sing a ballad about the history of Ardmore which mentions the towns patron saint, Saint Declan. It is believed he came to Ardmore from Wales in the early 5th Century. Some people say his missionary work may have pre-dated the activities of Saint Patrick.

On his arrival at Ardmore, St Declan set up a monastery which became the main church in what was known as the Kingdom of Disi Muman. This medieval monastery is known for its sculptures depicting scenes from The Bible. A round-tower was also added to the monastery in the 12th century.

On 26 August 1642, Lord Dungarvan and Lord Broghill set sail from Lismore to lay siege to the round tower and castle in Ardmore.

However, the people of Ardmore knew they were coming and about forty of them retreated to the round tower. This event is dramatised by the schoolchildren.

The whole event ended in disaster, the people had to surrender when the enemy brought in cannon from the sea the next day, Saturday 27 of August 1642, 117 people from Ardmore were hanged.

A Youngline report broadcast on 20 December 1979. The reporter is Ultan Guilfoyle.

Title: Images of Cork City, Ireland 1975
Description:
An impressionistic film evokes the sights and sounds of Cork city.

Writing about the film Images of the City of Cork in the RT Guide, John Walsh said,

Cork is Cork, and there is nowhere like it.

The film made by Norris Davidson takes a view of Cork from an outsiders perspective highlighting the places and buildings that the natives may take for granted.

Norris Davidson wanted the film to be,

A view of things in the city that strikes an outsider but are so familiar to the Corkonian that they may have become invisible to him.

There is no narration to this film which allows the images to speak for themselves. Images of the City of Cork was shot in May and June 1974.

Images of the City of Cork was broadcast on 10 January 1975.

Title: Unveiling the Occult in Ireland, 1986
Description:
The number of palmists and fortune tellers is a sign of an increased interest in otherworldly phenomena.

TV GAGA takes a look at astrology and the hidden world of the occult.

Astrology is but one detail in the much broader canvas of what we sometimes call the occult.

At Mary Street Shopping Arcade in Dublin, TV GAGAs Liam Mackey and Barbara Lee meet Kathleen Connors and Margaret Murphy who talk about the work of a professional fortune teller. They also speak to some customers. One young woman who is a frequent visitor says,

The cards never lie.

Another woman was surprised that the fortune teller could tell her so much about her past and present.

Barbara and Liam also meet some experts in the field and examine the complexities of the occult.

Gloria Hamilton of the Alchemists Head, a shop specialising in the occult and science fiction, explains the meaning behind the various tarot cards and dismisses the myths surrounding the dreaded death card.

Maitland Wolf, an Occultist, explains the meaning behind the occult and popular perceptions of the subject.

The word occult means hidden.

He takes a scientific approach, saying that everything happens in a sequence of cause and effect.

Magic is in the air in a north Dublin flat where members of a pagan group The Order of the Golden Morn gather for their fortnightly ritual on the night of the full moon. Liam and Barbara join the group to get an insight into their beliefs and rituals.

This episode of TV GAGA was broadcast on 30 January 1986. The presenters are Liam Mackey and Barbara Lee.

Title: Exploring Chapelizod Village with Frank Harte, 1988
Description:
Frank Harte shows Shay Healy around the Dublin village of Chapelizod.

A stroll through Chapelizod with architect, song collector and singer Frank Harte starts at Anna Livia Bridge over the river Liffey, renamed in 1982 in honour of the centenary of the birth of James Joyce.

James Joyce knew Chapelizod well, and it is the setting for the short story A Painful Case from the book Dubliners. The nearby Mullingar House also features centrally in Finnegans Wake in which publican Humphrey Chimpden Earwicker resides.

In Chapelizod Frank Harte points out derelict houses where families lived when he was growing up. The village is a stones throw from the Phoenix Park,

The area known as The Bank and New Row, was built to house distillery workers and their families.

Frank Hartes father owned and ran The Tap pub in the village, across the road from industrial buildings where in the seventeenth century flax and linen were processed. It then became a distillery and latterly a warehouse, before being destroyed by fire in recent years.

Another writer with Chapelizod connections is Gothic writer Joseph Sheridan Le Fanu (1814-1873). The village and environs provided inspiration for his ghost stories, horror fiction and many novels, in particular, The House of the Churchyard,

In his descriptions of it, and the house, you know he was here.

Just off Main Street is Saint Laurences Church of Ireland with its distinctive fifteenth-century square stone tower, which incorporates a section of a round tower. The site has for centuries been associated with the medieval tale of Tristan and Isolde.

Its from Isolde that the village got its name.

This episode of The Dublin Village was broadcast on 15 July 1988. The presenter is Shay Healy.

The Dublin Village was an eight-part series about the capitals urban villages broadcast in Dublins Millennium Year of 1988. The presenters were Shay Healy and Ingrid Miley.

Title: Interview with Miss Ireland 1985
Description:
The new Miss Ireland is an 18-year-old model from Artane in Dublin she talks to RT News about fashion and feminism.

Anne-Marie Gannon was crowned Miss Ireland at the National Concert Hall on 19 August 1985. She took over from the previous years winner, Olivia Treacy. Reporter Andrew Kelly met her in Herbert Park in Dublin the following day to find out what her new title meant to her.

Anne-Marie Gannon talks about her aspirations to be a top international model and break into the fashion business. She doesnt agree with those who criticize beauty contests:

I think women exploit women. I think the feminists exploit women, thats whats wrong. Theres too much feminism in this country..... If you stand an opportunity to represent your country in something, you should go ahead and do it.

She intends to do her best for Ireland at the Miss World contest in London in November.

An RT News report from 20 August 1985.

The 1985 Miss World Winner was Icelands Hlmfrur Karlsdttir. Anne-Marie Gannon was ranked in the top 10.

Title: Sweet Thames Flow Softly - Christy Moore, Sinad OConnor & Neill MacColl, 2001
Description:
Christy Moore on his love for the Ewan MacColl song Sweet Thames Flow Softly.

Christy Moore has a special admiration for the work of British singer-songwriter and activist Ewan MacColl. He recalls his first meeting with Ewan MacColl at the Singers Club in London. Christy Moore was incredibly nervous and recognizing this fact, Ewan MacColl bought him a single malt whiskey.

In 1965, Ewan MacColl and the American folksinger and musician Peggy founded the Critics Group, a learning group and an experimental musical theatre troupe. Ewan MacColl wrote Sweet Thames Flow Softly for a Critics Group production based on Romeo and Juliet.

Christy Moore first encountered Sweet Thames Flow Softly through a flatmate when he lived in Halifax in England. He fell in love with the song and has a deep admiration for the beauty of the lyric,

Took her sailin on the river,
Flow, sweet river, flow.
London town was mine to give her,
Sweet Thames Flow Softly.

Christy Moore performs Sweet Thames Flow Softly backed by singer Sinad OConnor and the singer and musician Neill MacColl. Neill MacColl is the son of Ewan MacColl and Peggy Seeger.

Christy Moore: The Songs of Ewan MacColl was broadcast on 11 November 2001.

Title: Clannad Celebrates 10th Anniversary in Donegal, 1979
Description:
Clannad are back in the Donegal Gaeltacht to celebrate their tenth anniversary with a concert in the family pub.

Folk superstars Clannad play to hundreds of thousands of fans around Europe each year. But no matter how far they travel, each year they play in the pub where they first got together, Leos Tavern (Tabhairne Leo), opened by their parents Leo and Mire (Baba) in 1968.

Bass player with Clannad Ciarn Brennan explains why the band returns home each year.

This area between Gweedore and Ranafast is the place where we get all the songs from and wed like to play the songs back to them with a different arrangement.

While at home the band members relax and recharge their batteries in readiness for their next tour which will see them play in America and Canada before returning to play in Europe again.

The band are celebrating ten years together and any initial pressures have long gone and the individual band members get along well as a group.

An RT News report broadcast on 16 August 1979.

Title: Tracing The Irish Race: We The Irish Documentary, 1971
Description:
In the 10-part documentary series We The Irish writers and historians Sen  Faolin, Conor Cruise OBrien and Owen Dudley Edwards analyse the Irish race in a bid to find out what made us the way we are today.

Sen  Faolin presents the first two programmes in the series, People and Place and Saints and Soldiers. Taking as a starting point the book Facts About Ireland published by the Department of External Affairs he enlarges its themes and develops them further.

All of it is true but its not all of the truth.

Like every race the Irish are the product of change, slow moving time and our environment.

Were different from other races because the influences that shaped us are different.

He argues that political events help to form the persona of a race, but he defines politics as

The response of a people to any forces that affect their fortunes as a people.

 Faolin shows how these responses developed over the centuries. He believes the end of the Ice Age some 8000 years ago is the most important single political event in Irelands story. Becoming an island apart from the rest of Europe allowed us to develop our own distinctive way of life in virtual isolation. He wonders

What manner of people were our earliest forbears who began to trickle in here on the Antrim coast about eight thousand years ago?

Sadly we know far more about the Pharaohs of Ancient Egypt than we do about our first islanders.

We The Irish: People And Place written and presented by Sen  Faolin was broadcast on 29 September 1971. Niall McCarthy was the series producer.

Description:
The Dubliners with special guests Jim McCann and Paddy Reilly. Ronnie Drew sings The Town I Loved So Well

Paddy Reilly, who has had major success with his version of the song, introduces the performance. The song is also long associated with the late Luke Kelly and was written by Phil Coulter.

Festival Folk is a six-part series featuring The Dubliners, with special guests Jim McCann and Paddy Reilly recorded in concert at the National Stadium in Dublin.

Title: Life in Cricklewood: Forgotten Irish Migrants, 2003
Description:
An extract from a Prime Time Investigates programme looking at the neglect of generations of economic migrants. These Irish people are forgotten by the country of their birth and often ignored by their adopted home.

In this extract Frank and Seamus, two Irish men who emigrated over thirty years ago, talk about their circumstances now living in London.

Seamus and Frank walking from their house in the Cricklewood area of London. Reporter Paul Rouse explains that for years Seamus and Frank worked on building sites all across London but their generation is now replaced by migrants from Eastern Europe.

A house is shown in Cricklewood, London thats shared by eight Irishmen. Seamus rent of 85 per week is paid by the local council to his Irish landlord. Seamus and Frank drink cider in Seamus squalid bed-sit. Another Irishman called Billy talks to them from the door. Seamus has lived here for 8 years; there is now no light, heat, or running water.

Seamus says there was electricity and gas but the landlady pulled the gas out. He says he is not receiving welfare. He says the lads are good to me, between that and the skips Im surviving; they know Ill bounce back.

Seamus shows the camera a wind-up radio which he describes as his best friend. Asked about his future he says, Im bang on 50. I dont really know you know? Im living day to day, if Celtic win Im happy, if they lose Im depressed. That is about the size of it. Id love to get out of this room, please God.

Frank, who is from County Longford, describes his flat consisting of a double-bed, a cooker and sink which doesnt work, and no hot water. He says his landlady wants 95 per week. He says there was a rat here recently, but the landlady says if you get the rat catcher out you pay him. Im not paying him, I worked all my life, paid all my taxes, now look where Im stuck, after all my work. Says when he was mugged and fell on hard times and he had an awful struggle getting a few pounds out of this government.

Franks room is decorated with Irish flags, maps, and trinkets.

There is a lot of paraphernalia here belonging to Ireland. I had to leave it but my heart is still there. My heart is still there that is why all the paraphernalia is up there. Why wouldnt it? I don't know how to say it..I had to leave it but I want to die in it.

Title: Ian Paisley Advocates for Independent Northern Ireland, 1974
Description:
DUP leader Ian Paisley has announced a policy shift from integration with Britain towards the possibility of an independent Northern Ireland.

Democratic Unionist Leader Rev Ian Paisley spoke about an independent Ulster in an interview with London Weekend Televisions Weekend World programme on 27 January. He admitted that his views on an independent Northern Ireland were against everything he had stood for. He then called for a referendum to be held so that people in the United Kingdom could decide if they wanted Northern Ireland to stay in the UK. Ian Paisleys policy shift has received mixed reactions in unionist circles.

In this Seven Days report, Stephen Preston journalist with the Sunday News Belfast discusses Ian Paisleys new stand for an independent Ulster.

Describing Ian Paisley as a warm-hearted and fun individual, he says,

His public image is certainly very different from his private one.

Stephen Preston says he is not surprised by Ian Paisleys new stance for an independent Ulster or anything that any loyalist or protestant says in Ulster.

He is talking about an independent Ulster.

This episode of Seven Days was broadcast on 1 February 1974. The reporter is Brendan OBrien.

Title: Exploring the History of Hook Peninsula, 1989
Description:
Exploring the history of Hook Peninsula with Wexford man Billy Colfer.

With its sandy beaches, fishing villages and beautiful scenery, the most southern part of County Wexford is scattered with Norman castles and locations where history was forged, and Irelands fortune changed.

The small fishing village of Ballyhack with its car ferry transporting cars and pedestrians to and from Passage East across the River Barrow, is overlooked by a fifteenth century tower house built by the Knights Hospitallers of St John, a Catholic military order later known as the Knights of Malta.

They took over the duties and lands of their rivals the Knights Templar following the orders dissolution in 1307. The Hospitallers had two other stone towers on the Hook Peninsula at Kilcloggan and Templetown.

Billy Colfer explains how the land was granted to the Knights Hospitallers by William Marshall, Earl of Pembroke. He was also Strongbows son in law, and the man who built the lighthouse tower at Hook Head. He brought the Knights to Ballyhack

Chun faire a choimead ar an ferry agus ar na bradin freisin a bh flirseach in san abhainn.

Baginbun headland, where Celtic tribes built a fortification known as Dn Dnaill, overlooks a beautiful sandy beach, frequented by both locals and the many visitors to this part of the sunny south east. This tranquil part of the peninsula has a dramatic and violent past.

It was here that Raymond le Gros FitzGerald landed with only a hundred or so soldiers in 1170, and changed the course of Irish history,

At the creek of Baginbun, Ireland was lost and won.

Centuries later a Martello tower was constructed on the headland circa 1805, as part of the British crowns defence against a possible invasion by Napoleon Bonaparte.

Nearby Slade is picturesque fishing village where catches of lobster, crab and mackerel are landed. It also has a castle, built by the Anglo-Norman Laffan family in the 15th century, who made their fortune from fishing and trading.

The castle and adjacent lands passed into the hands of the Loftus family in 1666, and it was they who constructed the harbour in 1684. Ten years later salt works buildings were added, but this industry had gone into decline by the nineteenth century.

The village of Fethard-On-Sea (the latter part of the name added in the early twentieth century to differentiate it from Fethard in County Tipperary) is another place owing its existence to the Norman invasion,

Bh an Fiodh rd ar ceann don na chad bailtigh a bhunaigh na hAngla-Normannaigh i gCondae Loch Garman.

The castle and the tower being the only mediaeval part remaining, was used mainly as a summer residence for the Bishop of Ferns, but after the Reformation became part of the Loftus familys estate.
The adjacent St Mogues Church, dating from 1684, was rebuilt in 1837, and is the final resting place of Alexander Devereux, the last Abbot of Dunbrody Abbey.

This episode of Sil Thart was broadcast on 7 October 1989. The reporter is Nuala N Dhomhnaill.

Title: Restoring Limerick's Historic Potato Market, 1987
Description:
The old Potato Market has been restored and is being given a new lease of life thanks to the Limerick Civic Trust.

Limerick got its first charter as a city in 1137, then the medieval settlement of Englishtown. On one corner of Kings Island is the site known as the Potato Market, which is reportedly the original site of the city of Limerick when it was founded by the Danes in 922.

The Potato Market is the latest jewel in the crown of the Limerick Civic Trust.

The Limerick Civic Trust is a voluntary body set up in 1983 with the objective of restoring and preserving the ancient and historic sites of Limerick.

A new pedestrian bridge, the Sylvester OHalloran Bridge has been built to link the Potato Market with the Custom House Quay. The bridge is named after a Limerick-born surgeon who pioneered cataract surgery.

Denis Leonard of the Limerick Civic Trust talks about the tradition of markets in Limerick and the work involved in restoring the market over a period of three years at a cost of almost 400,000. The newly restored market is intended for both locals and tourists.

It was a huge job. It was very derelict.

The Potato Market was originally opened in 1843 but fell into disrepair and disuse in the early 20th century. The restoration work was carried out by skilled craftsmen and AnCO trainees.

John Cosgrove remembers selling potatoes at the original market in 1925 and is delighted to see the new development. There are now plans to broaden the activities that take place at the Potato Market including hosting music festivals and open-air theatre.

This episode of Evening Extra was broadcast on 7 December 1987. The reporter is Shay Healy.

Evening Extra was a nightly magazine programme which ran from Monday to Friday at 7 pm dealing with current issues and people in the news. The first episode was aired on Monday 13 October 1986 and it ran for 278 shows over 2 years until the final show on 29 April 1988. The programme had numerous presenters and reporters including Siobhan Cleary, Richard Crowley, Bibi Baskin, Aonghus McAnally and Shay Healy.

Title: Limerick vs Kilkenny All-Ireland Hurling Final, 1973
Description:
The long wait ends for Limerick who are All Ireland Hurling Champions.

In pouring rain at Croke Park Limerick won the Liam McCarthy Cup for the first time since 1940. Perhaps the weather kept many away as the attendance of 58,009 was the lowest for an All Ireland Hurling Final in twenty-five years. The rain could not dampen the joyous scenes as Limerick supporters and players celebrated at the final whistle.

Limerick made the better start but when Pat Delaney scored a goal for Kilkenny after twenty minutes it put the Cats ahead by a point 1-03 to 0-05. Limerick regathered and pressure on the Kilkenny defence resulted in frees which Richie Bennis converted. By half-time, Limerick had the lead back again 0-12 to 1-07.

Within five minutes of the restart, the sides were level again. Then Frank Cummins went on a run sending a ball into Mick Crotty who looked like he must score a goal but Limerick goalkeeper Seamus Horgan made a remarkable save to deflect it over the bar. Kilkenny lead by one point 1-10 to 0-12. Shortly afterwards another Richie Bennis free levelled the game again.

Limerick attacked again and when Noel Skehan could only partially block a shot from Moss Dowling, the ball was bundled into the net after a goalmouth scramble. Bernie Hartigan added another point. Suddenly Limerick were four ahead 1-14 to 1-10. Although Kilkenny managed to close the gap to two points, Limerick were always able to keep their opponents at bay to secure victory.

In remarkable scenes of celebration, joyous Limerick supporters invaded the pitch. Captain amonn Grimes accepted the Liam McCarthy Cup as Limerick were crowned All Ireland Champions for the first time in thirty-three years.

The final score was Limerick 1-21 Kilkenny 1-14.

The All Ireland Hurling Final was broadcast live on 2 September 1973. The commentator is Michael OHehir.

Title: Street Name Confusion in Wexford Town, 1971
Description:
Although many streets in Wexford were renamed after participants in the Easter Rising, local people continue to refer to the original names.

Following a plebiscite in 1932, Wexford Council changed the towns street names to honour those who took part in the Easter Rising of 1916. However, locals still use the original street names and are often unaware of the new ones.

Frank Hall visits Wexford to investigate whether its citizens are familiar with the official street names or if they are still using the old names. He asks a number of people for directions and discovers that many of them are unfamiliar with James Connolly Street but can all point him in the direction of William Street.

A guide for the Old Wexford Society Sammy Coe explains the meaning behind the name Keyser Lane, the second oldest street in Wexford and the only one to escape renaming. He agrees the dual naming is confusing for tourists to Wexford. The street plates have new names but the old names are still in the guide books and maps of the town.

Im sure the Rising generation will eventually come around to the new name.

Some of the new names have caught on however, and Pearse Street is no longer referred to as Talbot Street. Wexford Corporation solely uses the new names in all official correspondence and fortunately for all, the Post Office is familiar with both versions.

This episode of Halls Pictorial Weekly was broadcast on 20 October 1971. The reporter is Frank Hall.

Title: Alternative Living in a Round House in Co. Clare, 1985
Description:
Colin and Marjorie Johnston have built a roundhouse and are looking to have a self-sufficient life in the Burren in County Clare.

Colin and Marjorie Johnston are part of the back-to-the-land movement that grew out of alternative ways of looking at society and lifestyles.

Having been given the use of what was previously scrub land, the couple went about clearing the ground and building a home for themselves and their animals.

Colin from Belfast and Marjorie from Portsmouth gave up city living to strive for rural self-sufficiency. Marjorie had always fantasised about living this kind of life but never believed that it could come true. The dream has become a reality having now lived their alternative lifestyle for the last seven years.

They have built a house without the use of any machinery using upcycled local stone and reeds for the roof.

According to Colin,

We both felt very much that we wanted to live in a round house. We both looked at various round structures.

Marjorie adds,

We also wanted something that would fit into the landscape I think, which I believe this does.

The house is based on the traditions of the type of housing in neolithic times when the building of roundhouses with thatched conical roofs was commonplace.

The process of construction may have been quite slow and hard on the hands but ultimately they found it very rewarding.

The Johnstons have also cultivated a vegetable garden, an orchard, and a herb garden. Marjorie is experimenting with using plants to dye wool and also for medicinal purposes.

This episode of Access was broadcast on 10 January 1985. The reporter is Ciana Campbell.

Access as the name suggests was a series of programmes made by young people for young people. The series advertised on television for ideas from young people.

With Access Community Television as a full title, the series began broadcasting on 24 November 1983. The content of each programme came from groups around the country who decided what topics would be covered. RT provided the expertise and technical means to make each programme which were presented by Ciana Campbell. The producer was Michael Murphy.

Title: Hottest Day of the Decade in Ireland, 2006
Description:
Temperatures soar as Ireland basks in sunshine.

The highest temperature was recorded at Kilkenny Castle. This is just the fourth time that temperatures in Ireland have entered the thirties in the past thirty years.

The highest temperature today was recorded at the Met station in Kilkenny.

As sun worshippers flocked to the seaside to make the most of the good weather, Emer OKane of the Irish Cancer Society warned the public about the potential dangers of staying out in the sun for too long.

An RT News report broadcast on 18 July 2006. The reporter is Anne Marie Smyth.

Title: Christ Church Cathedral: The House of Strongbow, 1978
Description:
A 950-year history of Christ Church Cathedral in Dublin.

One hundred years after the restoration of Christ Church Cathedral by the distiller, Henry Roe a look at the history of this famous Dublin landmark.

Though her silence be polluted by the roar of industry and her walls blackened by automobile fumes, Christ Church stands as her founders of another age intended.

Joseph Coady is the verger of Christ Church and his job is to provide access to the cathedral to all who wish to enter The House of Strongbow.

The history of Christ Church goes back to legends about Saint Patrick but recorded facts only began in the 9th century. Christ Church was founded by the Norsemen in 1038 when King Sigtrygg gave Bishop Dnn the hill of Dublin as a site for a cathedral.

The Very Rev Tom Salmon Dean of Christ Church describes the early days of Christ Church Cathedral as a simple, wooden structure. When the Normans arrived with their gift for building, Strongbow and St Laurence OToole began to rebuild the cathedral into the building that we know today. There have been several restorations over the years but the building remains exactly as Strongbow and St Laurence planned it.

Canon AE Stokes Member of the Board describes how in Elizabethan times in 1562, the main fabric of the building almost collapsed completely. The Lord Deputy Sir Henry Sidney carried out repairs which remained until Victorian times when the cathedral was completely renovated, funded by Dublin businessman and distiller Henry Roe.

A group of students are given a tour of the crypt of the cathedral.

The House of Strongbow was broadcast on 25 April 1978. The narrator is Bill Golding.

Title: Preparing for War in Ireland, 1962
Description:
The Civil Defence provides training to protect the population in the event of war.

The Dublin City Rescue Service carry out a simulated rescue operation in the event of a bomb attack at Ratra House in the Phoenix Park Dublin.

These are certainly dedicated people who do all their training in their spare time.

Mr J Fay, National Director of Civil Defence, explains what civil defence is all about.

Civil Defence means the efforts being made to organise the population to protect themselves against the effects of war, including particularly nuclear war.

When planning civil defence, order is required. The government has placed the hazard of radioactive fallout as the countrys biggest threat. Plans are made under the assumption that nuclear explosions could occur anywhere in the country and the Civil Defence must be prepared to act at short notice. To prepare for such events, the Civil Defence School has been established at the Phoenix Park. People are sent forward for training at the centre by their local authority. Courses are also carried out for An Garda Sochna, the army and other professionals such as water engineers and agricultural inspectors.

Chief Technical Officer at the Civil Defence School, Dr Aubrey Crawford explains how a chain of command operates throughout Ireland. The country is divided into eight regions made up of a number of counties. The counties are then subdivided into sub-counties and each sub-area is divided into districts which are again subdivided into warden post areas. In each of these areas, there are control posts.

You have a chain of command and control running right up.

Wardens in each of the districts use equipment to detect radioactive readings. Technical officer Mr Maher describes the different types of instruments used to detect radioactivity including the individual dosimeter, the different types of survey meters, and a contamination meter. Each of the instruments has different levels of sensitivity for measuring radioactivity.

If people are exposed to too much radiation, it would kill them and these instruments can tell exactly how much radiation is knocking around.

Another technical officer, Mr Dunne, describes some of the equipment required to feed people in the event of an attack where there is a loss of electricity or gas power. These include single and double dustbin ovens, a stockpot boiler and a series of basic cookers for pot boiling. All of these devices are made from debris which can be found following a bomb blast. The mobile feeding units are designed to feed two thousand people every four hours.

If there is a nuclear war, you may not know what to do, I may not know what to do, but at least its good to know that in this country there are people who can tell us.

An RT News report broadcast on 2 July 1962.

Title: The Twelfth Celebrations in Northern Ireland, 1976
Description:
The Orange celebrations in Ulster begin on 1st July when many parades take place to commemorate the Battle of the Somme and culminate in the spectacular parades of the Twelfth Day.

The Twelfth celebrations are characterised first and foremost by their colour, music and vitality. However, for many, the deep-rooted tradition behind the festivities is overshadowed by the political element. To correct the balance, The Sash My Father Wore takes a sympathetic view of the July celebrations. There is no analysis, just a commentary from lifelong Orange Order members Joe Gibson and Billy McKeon.

Billy McKeon believes life is too short for sectarianism. For thirty years he worked in Belfast as a bus driver in the predominantly nationalist Short Strand Depot where his Roman Catholic colleagues christened him Orange Billy. He had to ask a Catholic for time off on the Twelfth, but this was never a problem.

McKeon would have loved to have been a great musician. He competed on the pipe in the All Ireland Contest and has played in Dublin and Howth with pipe bands. As he sees it, the very existence of a band in Northern Ireland is primarily to take part in the Twelfth demonstration or any other Orange demonstrations.

Speaking as an Ulster man, I must confess that I know all the Orange tunes, and the Twelfth of July wouldnt be the Twelfth of July if I didnt hear The Sash and Dollys Ring and one or two others.

The Sash My Father Wore was first broadcast on 12 July 1976. The producer is Joe Mulholland.

Title: Pure Ireland: Early Christian Ireland, 1967
Description:
Knowledge of early Christianity in Ireland has come mainly from written text sources.

Little of the material evidence of Irelands early years remains with much of the information about early Christian Ireland gathered from written sources rather than from monuments or shrines.

The Christianity of Ireland was a powerful force exerting mighty influence at home and abroad.

In 431, Christian writer and disciple of Augustine of Hippo, Prosper of Aquitaine, wrote,

Ad Scotum in Christum credentes, to the Irish believing in Christ, Palladius has sent use their first bishop

This is a clear indication that prior to 431 when Palladius came to organise them, there was a sufficient body of Christians already in Ireland to warrant his mission. It is thought that these Christians were located mainly in the south, an area which had been in close contact with the mainland of Europe. It is considered that they were organised on a diocesan basis, similar to how the church was administered in Europe. There are no certain relics of this early period of Christianity in Ireland with the possible exception of a reliquary box found with a skeleton in a stone lined grave beneath the round tower in Dromiskin, County Louth.

A carefully hollowed stone box with a sliding lid containing a smaller wooden hollow box also with a sliding lid and secured by a bar of bronze.

It is not clear how long the Roman system of diocesan organisation lasted but it was not too long before Patrick, the successor of Palladius, was able to the write that the sons and daughters of the Irish were in great numbers becoming monks and virgins of Christ. In the 5th century, monasticism arrived in Ireland.

Heritage: Island of Saints was broadcast on 12 July 1967. The presenter is Dr Joseph Raftery and the programme was produced by Pat Baker.

The programme Heritage was a seven part survey of Irish archaeology from early times to the Cistercian Reform and the Norman Invasion. It was written by Dr Joseph Raftery, President of the Royal Irish Academy (RIA).

Title: Reaction to Clare Winning All Ireland Hurling Final, 1995
Description:
Clare beat Offaly to become the All Ireland Hurling Champions RT News got the post match reaction from supporters.

Clare won the 1995 All Ireland Hurling Final 81 years after the last victory for the Banner county.

Reporter Paul Reynolds gets the reaction from fans outside Croke Park after the game including one unique celebration from a gentleman who removes his false teeth to give the Clare shout.

Waited over 80 years for todays victory.

An RT News report broadcast 3 September 1995. The reporter is Paul Reynolds.

Title: John Hurt Interview, 2002
Description:
John Hurt looks back at his younger days and talks about how he always had the acting bug. He also recalls meeting Samuel Beckett.

Actor John Hurt talks to Pat Kenny about growing up and the influence his Anglican clergyman father had on him,

He was a good performer, I might say, a very good preacher  short, very abrupt, clear, clean, all of that.

By chance, John Hurt was befriended by two Australian women who he met in London and credits them with being the people who set him on the path that led to a long and distinguished acting career,

They looked after me and decided that they would go and get the forms necessary for RADA. The rest is history.

John Hurt was fortunate enough to meet his hero Samuel Beckett although it was only once he remembers the occasion fondly and was surprised to find him reading the racing pages.

This episode of The Late Late Show was broadcast on 22 February 2002. The presenter is Pat Kenny.

Title: Buncrana Fleadh Cheoil, 1975
Description:
A visit to Fleadh Cheoil na hireann in Buncrana seen through the eyes of a young man from Ballyfermot.

Fleadh Cheoil na hireann, a national festival of traditional Irish music established by Comhaltas Ceoltir ireann, was first held in Mullingar in 1951. Over the years the Fleadh Cheoil has been held in many different towns throughout Ireland and in August 1975 it was the turn of Buncrana, County Donegal.

This was the first time the festival had been hosted in Donegal. RT producer Tom Walsh was in Buncrana to capture the sights and sounds of the festival for television.

Commenting on the programme in the RT Guide Tom Walsh says,

"I deliberately have no commentary. The idea behind the film is to capture the flavour of the event. To make that even more real, we see the Fleadh through the eyes of a young lad from Ballyfermot, Terry Flood."

This approach means that the cameras stay mainly on the streets, recording impromptu sessions from folk musicians to be found at every corner of Buncrana.

The programme follows Terry Flood from Ballyfermot in Dublin as he wanders the streets taking in the music of the festival.

The programme Fleadh Cheoil in Donegal was broadcast on Easter Monday 19 April 1976. The programme was broadcast again in 1991 to mark 40 years of Comhaltas Ceoltir ireann.

The Fleadh Cheoil was hosted again in Buncrana the following year in 1976.

Title: The Sheep Who Thinks it's a Dog, Castletownroche, Co. Cork, Ireland 1998
Description:
Mac is a Cork sheep who truly believes that he is a dog.

Rescued as a lamb last spring, Mac was hand reared by Shirley Ladd on her fathers farm in Castletownroche. All of Macs life to date has been spent with the farm dogs. He is one of them now, says Shirley Ladd,

Hes always been with dogs...thats what he is in his own mind.

This inquisitive, independent and sociable sheep shows no sign of having the herd instinct. He prefers to go for long walks with his canine buddies. Tom Ladd explains that Mac will ramble along happily for hours, enjoying the sights and sounds of the Cork countryside,

Theres great excitement to find a rabbit.

Participating in as many aspects of farm life as he can, Mac is very much part of the pack,

He just cant bear to be left behind.

This report for Nationwide was broadcast on 16 February 1998. The reporter is Donna OSullivan.

Title: Reviving Traditional Aran Knitwear in Galway, Ireland 1963
Description:
*The footage shown here has no audio.

Discover the legacy of Aran knitwear in a Gaeltacht village shop that has become a symbol of Irish heritage.

Broadsheet visits Standun Gaillimh Teo, located in An Spidal, County Galway. Famous for its iconic Aran sweaters and knitwear, Standun was established in 1946 by May and Mirtn Standn and quickly attracted customers from across Ireland.

With over 500 home knitters producing a variety of Aran knitwear featuring distinct patterns like cable, moss, and trinity stitches, Standun's items are made from binn wool, which retains the natural lanolin of sheep. After collection, these hand-knit items undergo finishing touches at the shop's factory in An Spidal, where they are graded, sized, and packaged.

Each finished piece is tagged with an official Standun label, signed by the individual knitter, adding a personal touch. The shop's exterior often features people modeling these unique Aran garments.

This episode of Broadsheet was originally broadcast on 22 February 1963. Broadsheet was a magazine programme that aired on weekday evenings throughout the 1960s.

Title: Christy Dignam's Journey: From Addiction to Aslan's Return, 2004
Description:
Explore the turbulent life of Aslans lead singer Christy Dignam, his battle with addiction, and the band's triumphant return.

Christy Dignam's memoir, This is... Christy Dignam, chronicles his struggle with heroin addiction, his dismissal from Aslan, and the band's eventual comeback. Five years after hitting rock bottom, Christy rejoined Aslan, and they have since continued to make music together.

Aslan guitarist Billy McGuinness emphasizes that the story serves as a cautionary tale about the music industry's dark side. The book also delves into Christys efforts to overcome the trauma of childhood abuse.

Co-author Neil Fetherstonhaugh was surprised by the depth of Christys story, revealing many unknown aspects of his life. Aslan is currently working on their seventh album, with plans to release a new single soon.

Title: Josie McDermott's Award-Winning Lament, 1978
Description:
Celebrate Josie McDermott's composition that earned him first prize for a new lament in traditional Irish musical style.

The Merriman Winter School in Ballyvaughun, County Clare, hosted a competition for new laments or slow airs in traditional Irish music, organized by Cumann Merriman in collaboration with RT. Seventy-year-old Josie McDermott from Coolmeen, Ballyfarnon in County Roscommon, won with his composition Lament For a Fiddle Player.

The 150 prize was presented by RTs Head of External Affairs, Sen Mac Ramoinn. Josie McDermott, primarily known as a traditional flute player, is a multi-instrumentalist with a passion for jazz and modern music, and a deep interest in the works of blind harpist and composer Turlough OCarolan. Despite losing his sight at 37, Josie continued to excel in his musical pursuits.

The competition received nearly 100 entries from 20 counties in Ireland, as well as entries from England and Scotland.

An RT News report broadcast on 29 January 1978. The reporter is Nuala N Dhomhnaill.

Title: Roscommon Farmer's Independent Record Label, Ireland 1997
Description:
Explore the unique story of Anthony Brennan, a dairy farmer from Roscommon, who runs the independent record label Wednesday Works alongside his farming duties.

Anthony Brennan, based in Cloghermore near Elphin, juggles dairy farming with managing an independent record label. Founded during a night out in Tulsk, Wednesday Works released its first record by Dublin band Serious Women in early 1994. Brennan, alongside two fellow farmers, funds and operates the label, focusing on music they believe in rather than profit.

David Constantine of Serious Women praises Brennans genuine passion for music, while Peter Jones of Dublin punk band Paranoid Visions recalls Brennans initial naivety about the record-making process. Despite this, Wednesday Works has produced numerous records, including singles for The Acrobats of Desire, emphasizing creativity over commercial success.

This episode of Popscene was broadcast on 1 November 1997. The reporter is Pearse Lehane.

Title: Assessing Ireland's EEC Membership: A Decade On, 1983
Description:
Ten years after joining the EEC, what has membership done for Ireland and what contribution has Ireland made to Europe?

In 1973, Ireland, along with the United Kingdom and Denmark, joined the European Economic Community (EEC). Ten years on, Today Tonight examines the impact that membership of the community has had on Ireland.

Interviews from the time reflect peoples hopes, aspirations, and fears ahead of joining the EEC and the common market. Irelands entry to the EEC was decided by referendum with 83% of the electorate voting to join.

Ireland joined the EEC largely in a spirit of optimism with an expectation of higher standards of living, higher prices for agricultural products, new industrial markets, and more jobs. Una Claffey examines whether the reality of membership has lived up to expectations.

Reporter Una Claffey looks back at the foundation of the community and what the future holds for the common European market with contributions from Gaston Thorn, President of the Commission of the European Parliament, and commissioners Brendan McNamara, Eamon Gallagher, and Dr. Tom Dwyer.

This episode of Today Tonight was broadcast on 10 January 1983. The reporter is Una Claffey.

Title: Ancient Monuments and Burial Rites in Ireland, 1967
Description:
Exploring the archaeological insights into ancient Irish burial practices and the significance of megalithic tombs.

This RT documentary delves into the memorials and burial rites of ancient Ireland, highlighting the Neolithic period's grave types, including pits, cists, and megalithic tombs. Approximately 1,300 megaliths survive in Ireland, including passage graves, court cairns, wedge-shaped tombs, and dolmens like the renowned Newgrange.

Title: Housing Crisis: 350,000 Vacant Properties in Ireland, 2010
Description: In 2010, nearly 350,000 houses and apartments in Ireland were vacant, accounting for 17% of the total housing stock. Outside Dublin, over 20% of properties were empty. Researchers from University College Dublin revealed that, excluding holiday homes, empty rentals, and derelict houses, there were still 170,000 vacant units. This RT News report by Sharon Tobin, broadcast on 5 March 2010, features insights from Brendan Williams of UCD, who questions the demand for these properties outside urban areas.

Title: St. Patrick's Day Parade in Moscow, 1993
Description: Mairad N Nuadhin provides a vibrant account of the St. Patricks Day Parade in Moscow, showcasing a lively display of floats and marching bands. The parade, held in 1993, brought a piece of Irish culture to the streets of Moscow, captivating the local audience.

Title: Cork Locals Reflect on Their First Kisses, 1968
Description: In a heartwarming 'Newsbeat' report from 18 December 1968, Cork residents share fond memories of their first kisses. The candid interviews reveal humorous and nostalgic stories, from a first kiss during a game of 'spin the bottle' to the challenge of kissing someone taller by standing on a brick.

Title: Student Life and Challenges at University College Cork, 1966
Description: Are the ideals of light, liberty, and learning realized at University College Cork? Newsbeat visits the UCC campus to explore students' perspectives on their education. Many feel they are spoon-fed facts rather than taught how to think critically. The Philosophical Society at UCC argues that the ideals have been defeated by the system. With growing student numbers and limited facilities, frustrations are high. UCC's President Dr. JJ McHenry responds to these concerns. This episode of 'Newsbeat' was broadcast on 19 December 1966. The reporter is Bill OHerlihy.

Title: Celebrating Irish Music: The Stag Hot Press Awards 1984
Description: Vincent Hanley hosts the fourth annual Stag Hot Press Irish Music Awards at the National Stadium in Dublin, celebrating the achievements of Irish artists on the international music scene. Notable winners include Moving Hearts, Christy Moore, and Chris de Burgh. The event also honored previous winners like U2, Clannad, and Van Morrison. The Best New Act award was shared by Les Enfants and In Tua Nua. Jim Aiken received a special award for services to the music industry. This broadcast was part of RTs Festival Week series on 20 September 1984.

Title: Clare Hurlers Triumph in Munster Final, 1997
Description: The Clare hurling team and their supporters celebrate a historic victory in the Munster Senior Hurling Final against Tipperary, their first win in a Munster final since 1899. The Usual Place pub in Ennis was packed with fans reliving the 1-18 to 0-18 victory. Player Ger Sparrow OLoughlin and goalkeeper Davy Fitzgerald share their excitement and confidence for future successes. This RT News report was broadcast on 7 July 1997. The reporter is Tony ODonoghue.

Title: Second Annual Fleadh Nua at Croke Park, 1971
Description: The second Fleadh Nua, organized by Comhaltas Ceoltir ireann, brings Irish dancing and cultural festivities to Croke Park. Children perform traditional Irish dances on the pitch, accompanied by Paddy Glackin in period costume. With hopes of doubling last year's attendance, the event promises to be a major national cultural celebration. An RT News report broadcast on 6 June 1971.

Title: The Cranberries' Triumphant Return to Limerick, 1993
Description: After a successful American tour, The Cranberries return to Limerick for two homecoming concerts. Their debut album has sold over one million copies in the US, making it the most successful debut album by an Irish act there. The band receives a rapturous reception and a Mayoral welcome. Dolores ORiordan and Fergal Lawler express their delight at the enthusiastic homecoming. The Cranberries perform at the Limerick Theatre Royal on 17 December and the Dublin Tivoli on 18 December 1993. An RT News report by Cathy Halloran broadcast on 17 December 1993.

Title: Love and Marriage in Rural Ireland, 1969
Description: With low marriage rates in rural Ireland, the Catholic Church takes steps to help farmers find wives. Young farmers in Glenamaddy, County Galway, attend etiquette classes to learn how to date. Many rural women have moved to Dublin, leaving men like Jimmy Glynn living alone on small farms. The Lisdoonvarna Festival and matchmaking efforts by local priests like Father Michael Kane offer potential solutions. 'Radharc: The New Matchmakers' explores these initiatives. First broadcast on 2 November 1969, the reporter is Father Peter Lemass.

Title: The Astronomical Legacy of William Parsons and Birr Castle Telescope, 1976
Description:
Explore the achievements of William Parsons, the Third Earl of Rosse, who constructed the Leviathan of Parsonstown at Birr Castle in County Offaly. This massive reflecting telescope, with a 72-inch diameter mirror, was the largest and most powerful of its time in 1845. Despite skepticism, Parsons' innovation unveiled new astronomical wonders. Featuring Conor Evans as the Earl of Rosse and Chris Curran as Rev Robinson. An episode of 'Irish Men and Irish Women' broadcast on 15 December 1976, presented by Ronnie Drew.

Title: Ted Kennedy's Sentimental Journey to Ireland, 1962
Description:
Edward Kennedy, the youngest brother of President John F Kennedy, pays a private visit to Ireland to visit his relations in County Wexford. Following his arrival at Dublin airport on 25 February 1962, reporter Frank Hall speaks with Ted Kennedy about his visit and political plans. Kennedy expresses his delight to be in Ireland and his eagerness to visit the Kennedy ancestral home in Dunganstown. He describes the trip as purely sentimental and reflects on his recent fact-finding mission about the Common Market in mainland Europe. An RT News report broadcast on 26 February 1962, reported by Frank Hall.

The New Zealand manager and captain reflect on their ongoing tour, including an upcoming game against Leinster. The All Blacks tour includes internationals against England, Scotland, Wales, Ireland, and France, as well as games against club and provincial teams. Manager Ernie Todd and captain Ian Kirpatrick discuss their young team's performance and expectations for the match against Leinster on 15 November at Lansdowne Road, Dublin. Title: Thrills and Heartbreak at the 1978 Munster Hurling Final
Description:
The Munster Hurling Final, played in Thurles, is one of the highlights of the Irish sporting calendar. Over 54,000 hurling fans gathered to witness the clash between Cork and Clare. Cork supporters were confident, given their history of success, while Clare fans hoped for their first Munster title since 1932. Doireann N Bhriain reports on the range of emotions felt by players and supporters. President of Ireland Patrick Hillery, a Clare man, and Taoiseach Jack Lynch, a Cork man, were present. Cork emerged victorious, with captain Charlie McCarthy praising Clare's effort. Despite the loss, Clare's Ger Loughnane and coach Father Harry Bohan remain defiant, promising a strong return. The final score was Cork 0-13 Clare 0-11. This report for P.M. was broadcast on 1 July 1978.

Title: Controversial Kissing Contest in Mayo, 1985
Description:

Opinions were mixed, with some locals viewing it as fun. An RT News report broadcast on 1 April 1985.

Title: Cruising the River Shannon, 1981
Description:
Cruises on the Shannon are popular, but more visitors are needed to boost tourism. The tourist board has long aimed to attract more visitors to the River Shannon, which remains quieter than expected. While cruising numbers increased slightly last year, many companies struggle to survive. The cost to navigate through locks and bridges is a mere 17 pence, unchanged for years. A lock keeper suggests a price increase could benefit maintenance and appeal to tourists. This report is part of a series examining tourism in the River Shannon region, featuring music from Wicklow ballad group Aisling. Notable acts like U2, Def Leppard, The Chieftains, and Clannad have used the facilities. In 1986, music video director Meiert Avis finalizes a video for the Thompson Twins' song King For A Day at the studio, using the Royal Hospital Kilmainham as a set. Meanwhile, producer and Fastway guitarist Fast Eddie Clarke, along with producer/engineer Will Reid-Dick, records vocals with singer Dave King for the soundtrack of the 1986 heavy metal horror film Trick or Treat. This report, featuring insights into the creative process at Windmill Lane, was broadcast on 25 July 1986 by RT News, with Vere Wynne Jones reporting.

Title: Exploring the Unique Landscape of The Burren, 1979
Description:
The 1979 Breathing Space series takes viewers to The Burren in Co. Clare, a unique landscape composed of ancient limestone slabs. Fergus OGorman describes the area as a place where, 300 million years ago, shelly sea creatures fell to the seabed, contributing to the formation of this extraordinary terrain. This episode, which aired on 15 October 1979, highlights The Burrens geological and historical significance, offering a serene view of one of Irelands most distinctive natural environments.

During the second concert, dedicated to  Riadas traditional music, accordion player Tony MacMahon performed the haunting slow air Port na bPca, a tune originating from the Blasket Islands. This annual Irish music competition, organized by Comhaltas Ceoltir ireann, has been a staple of Irish cultural life since its inception in 1951. The Fleadh Cheoil showcases the best in traditional Irish music, dance, and song, attracting participants and spectators from all over the world. This RT News report captures the lively atmosphere and musical talent on display during the event, broadcast on 27 August 1978.

Title: Jack Charlton Reflects on Life Before Football, 1987

In a 1987 interview on The Late Late Show, Jack Charlton, the manager of the Republic of Ireland football team, reflects on his life before football. Growing up as the son of a miner, Charlton worked briefly in the mines before pursuing a career in football with Leeds United. With 629 appearances for Leeds, 35 caps for England, and a World Cup win, Charlton's achievements are celebrated. He shares memories of his early life, his transition from mining to football, and his admiration for Arthur Scargill's efforts for miners' rights. This interview was part of The Late Late Show broadcast on 11 December 1987, hosted by Gay Byrne.

Title: Michael Cusack: GAA Founder, 1976
