Title: Unique Irish Dancing by John Conneely, 1973
Description: Experience the captivating Irish dancing of John Conneely from Knock, County Mayo, as he performs to Miss McLeods Reel. The music is provided by Na Fil, featuring Matt Cranitch on fiddle, Tom Barry on whistle, and Toms  Canainn on uilleann pipes. John Conneely briefly shares the dance floor with Aidan OHara. This episode of Meitheal aired on 28 April 1973. The show 'Meitheal' brought together traditional and modern music, song, and dance.

Title: Captain Fitzmaurices Historic Transatlantic Flight, 1928
Description: In 1928, Captain James Fitzmaurice from Dublin, along with Germans Hermann Khl and Baron von Hnefeld, made aviation history with the first east-west transatlantic flight from Ireland to America. Taking off from Baldonnel Aerodrome on 12 April 1928, their aircraft, the Bremen, landed on Greenly Island, Canada, 36.5 hours later. Celebrations for the 70th anniversary of this feat included the publication of Fitz - and the Famous Flight by Teddy Fennelly and the unveiling of a statue. Captain Aidan Quigley reflects on the bravery of this pioneering flight. This RT News report was broadcast on 4 January 1998.

Title: Rory Gallagher Discusses 'Defender' Album, 1988
Description: Legendary guitarist Rory Gallagher shares insights into his latest album Defender, his decision to scrap the album Torch, and his experiences touring behind the Iron Curtain. Rory expresses satisfaction with the mood of Defender and reflects on the low-key but intriguing nature of his Eastern bloc tour. Despite global success, Rory remains grounded and private. This episode of Borderline aired on 1 March 1988, hosted by Ronan Johnston and Maria Doyle.

Title: Dublin City Marks 50th Anniversary of the Easter Rising, 1966
Description: A military parade and ceremony outside the General Post Office in Dublin commenced the events marking the 50th anniversary of the Easter Rising. Veterans from 1916 and the War of Independence were present in the reviewing stand at the GPO. President de Valera, accompanied by Colonel Sen Brennan, inspected the FCA guard before joining the stand. Thousands of spectators lined the route, watching the Irish Defence Forces led by Colonel Dan Fitzgerald cross OConnell Bridge in an open jeep. The parade featured Infantry, Artillery, Cavalry, Air, Medical, and Military Police Corps, with the Navy represented by An Slua Muiri members. Four Vampire jets and helicopters flew overhead.

Title: Mexican Pilot's Emergency Landing at Mallow Racecourse, 1983
Description: On 18 April 1983, Captain Ruben Ocana made an emergency landing at Mallow Racecourse after running low on fuel. Stranded in Mallow for 39 days, Captain Ocana and his crew awaited the construction of a runway to get their Gulfstream II jet airborne again. During the Rakes of Mallow Festival, reporter Pat Butler visited the town to speak with Captain Ocana and track the runway's progress. Locals who witnessed the landing praised the pilot's skill, and the emergency landing was even re-enacted during the festival. Captain Ocana settled into the Central Hotel, becoming a local celebrity and even judging a beauty pageant.

Title: The World of Competitive Bodybuilding in Ireland, 1967
Description: Competitive bodybuilding is not just about keeping fit; it's about sculpting the body to achieve an aesthetic form. Men like Paddy Byrne put in hard work at gyms such as the Apollo Club in Dublin to develop rippling pectorals and swelling calf muscles. This intense physical training involves using various machines and weights, some of which resemble medieval torture devices. Billy Higgins, Secretary of the Irish Amateur Weight Lifting Association, explains that motivations range from improving physique for sports to seeking self-satisfaction. During competitions, judges look for overall body development and proportionate physiques.

Title: The Road to Independence: Exhibition on the 1916 Rising, 1991
Description: On the 75th anniversary of the 1916 Rising, the National Museum of Ireland launched 'Ar Thoir Na Saoirse' (The Road to Independence) exhibition, chronicling the events leading to the Anglo-Irish Treaty in 1921. Opened by Minister for Defence Brendan Daly, the exhibition features artifacts like the 'Book of Ballykinlar' from 1921. Director Pat Wallace highlights the historical significance and mentions past exhibitions on the 25th and 50th anniversaries. This RT News report was broadcast on 24 April 1991, with Fionnuala Sweeney reporting.

Title: Sharon Shannon & Friends Perform The Kerry Polkas, 1992
Description: In a special 'Late Late Show' episode, musician Sharon Shannon is celebrated for her contributions to Irish music. Known for blending traditional Irish music with various influences, Sharon performs 'The Kerry Polkas' with fellow artists and friends. The show features contributions from numerous musicians, including Eleanor McEvoy, Mary Black, Dnal Lunny, and Adam Clayton. This episode aired on 18 December 1992, hosted by Gay Byrne.

Title: Elvis Presley Birthday Celebration in Dublin, 1971
Description: Elvis Presley fans in Dublin gather at Morans Hotel to celebrate his 36th birthday. They discuss what makes Elvis special to them, from his looks and personality to the quality of his music. Despite Elvis never having performed in Ireland, his fans remain hopeful. This 'Newsbeat' report was broadcast on 8 January 1971.

Title: Ronald Reagan's Ancestral Roots in Tipperary, 1980
Description: Ballyporeen, County Tipperary, gains attention as the ancestral home of U.S. President Ronald Reagan. Researchers from Debretts Peerage and Baronetage link Reagans great-grandfather Michael Regan to the village. Pub owners John and Mary OFarrell recount their surprise at the discovery. Father Eanna Condon verifies the findings with the parish register. This 'Irelands Eye' report by Pat Butler aired on 19 November 1980.

Title: Prefab Sprout Perform 'Cars and Girls' on The Late Late Show, 1988
Description: Paddy McAloon and Prefab Sprout take to the stage on 'The Late Late Show' to perform their hit 'Cars and Girls'. Despite never having a number one single, Gay Byrne praises the band for their album sales and predicts continued success for their latest album From Langley Park to Memphis, which features guest musicians Pete Townshend and Stevie Wonder. This episode aired on 15 April 1988.

Title: Corks Traditional Delicacies Explored by James N Healy, 1972
Description: Cork actor James N Healy takes a nostalgic look at traditional local foods, crubeens (boiled pigs' feet) and tripe, lamenting their decline in the city. Healy attributes this to the closure of Katty Barrys sheebeen and the rise of international cuisine. Demonstrating how to enjoy these delicacies, Healy visits Corks English Market. This segment aired on Halls Pictorial Weekly on 2 December 1972.

Title: The Landlord and Tenant Act: Homeowners' Struggles, 1967
Description: The Landlord and Tenant (Ground Rents) Act of 1967 aimed to allow tenants to buy out their freehold, but complexities in leases have left some homeowners vulnerable. Residents of the Proby Estate in Dublin face high costs and uncertain futures due to their lease terms. This episode of Seven Days aired on 20 October 1967, reported by David Thornley.

Title: Bean Dubh An Ghleanna - Catherine Ennis, Liam OFlynn & Sen Keane, 1997
Description: In a captivating performance recorded at Adam and Eves Church in Dublin, organist Catherine Ennis teams up with renowned piper Liam OFlynn and celebrated fiddler Sen Keane to perform the haunting slow air Bean Dubh An Ghleanna. This episode of 'The High Reel', presented by Maired N Mhaonaigh, aired on 6 May 1997.

Title: Future Development Plans for Cork City, 1978
Description: The Cork Land Use and Transportation Study outlines ambitious plans for Cork, including three new bridges, increased pedestrian zones, higher parking fees, and a tunnel under the River Lee. The study aims to strategically grow and develop the Cork region, with significant changes expected over a 13-year period. This RT News report, aired on 14 September 1978, is presented by Tom MacSweeney.

Title: Ronnie Drew Presents the Story of Scientist Richard Kirwan, 1977
Description: Ronnie Drew tells the story of Richard Kirwan, an 18th-century scientist from County Galway. Kirwan made significant contributions to meteorology, chemistry, mineralogy, and geology, and was a founding member of the Royal Irish Academy. This episode of Irish Men and Irish Women aired on 24 October 1977.

Title: Noel Gallagher Talks Fame and Music on The Late Late Show, 1996
Description: Noel Gallagher, songwriter and guitarist of Oasis, discusses handling fame, learning the guitar, and the band's enthusiastic fans. Despite the fame, Gallagher remains grounded thanks to his family and friends. This episode of The Late Late Show aired on 22 March 1996, hosted by Gay Byrne.

Title: Dubliners Share Their Views on Arts and Literature, 1968
Description: As part of a review on the arts in Ireland, '7 Days' interviews Dubliners about their engagement with theatre, art, poetry, and literature. Opinions vary widely, with some expressing love for classical theatre and others preferring cinema or books from libraries. This '7 Days' report aired on 13 September 1968, presented by John ODonoghue.

Title: Belfast Reacts to Bobby Sands' Death, 1981
Description: Bobby Sands died after 66 days on hunger strike on 5 May 1981. This RT report by Forbes McFall covers the reaction in Belfast, with statements from the Northern Ireland Office and community responses. The death is marked by unrest in West Belfast and varied opinions on its impact on English rule in Ireland. A Today Tonight report aired on 5 May 1981.

Title: Hippie Commune on Dorinish Island, 1971
Description: Newsbeat investigates the conflict between the residents of Westport, County Mayo and the hippies living on Dorinish Island. Led by Sid Rawle, the group aims to create an alternative society, despite opposition from locals who view their presence as a threat. This Newsbeat report, featuring commentary from local residents and the hippies, aired on 7 January 1971.

Title: Planxty Live at National Stadium, 1973
Description: Planxty performs 'Kitty Gone A Milking' and 'Music of the Forge' at the National Stadium in Dublin. The original line-up includes Dnal Lunny, Andy Irvine, Liam g OFlynn, and Christy Moore. This concert was filmed in 1972 and broadcast as part of 'The Music Makers' series on 18 June 1973.

Title: O'Carolan Harp Festival in Keadue, 1982
Description: The OCarolan Harp Festival in Keadue, County Roscommon, honors the famed harper and composer Turlough OCarolan. This RT News report from 4 August 1982 by Mchel  hUanachin highlights open-air harp concerts, traditional music sessions, and various festival activities.

Title: Gallagher Family on Life with Oasis, 1996
Description: Peggy Gallagher and her eldest son Paul discuss their experiences as family members of Oasis, one of the world's most successful bands. Pauls book 'Brothers: From Childhood To Oasis - The Real Story' details their journey. This interview aired on The Late Late Show on 20 September 1996.

Title: Life on Shankill Road, Belfast, 1976
Description: An in-depth look at the loyalist stronghold of Shankill Road in Belfast. Residents share their experiences and perspectives on life in the area, including scenes from the Bayardo Bar. This '7 Days' report aired on 12 October 1976.

Title: Reviving Clonakilty: A Conservation Effort, 1987
Description: Traditional shopfronts and hand-painted signs are being revived as part of Clonakilty's conservation. The town's development plan, championed by architect Billy Houlihan, balances the conservation of old buildings with new developments. The restoration of Chateaulin Park and the Old Mill on Kent Street are examples of this effort. Toms Tuipar, a third-generation sign writer, contributes to the town's unique character with his bilingual signs. This 'Crsa' report was broadcast on 5 May 1987.

Title: Emmet Dalton on The 1916 Easter Rising, 1978
Description: Emmet Dalton recounts his reaction to the outbreak of the 1916 Easter Rising. At the time, he and his fellow soldiers were surprised and thought it was madness. Dalton, who felt no sympathy for the rebels, believed that their cause had no hope of success. This interview with Cathal OShannon provides insight into his perspective. Broadcast on 27 November 1978.

Title: Irish National Anthem: Seven Signatories Version, 1966
Description: A specially commissioned version of the Irish national anthem was shown at the stations close each evening during Easter week in 1966. The anthem was played alongside portraits of the seven signatories of the proclamation: Thomas J. Clarke, Sen Mac Diarmada, Thomas MacDonagh, Patrick Pearse, amonn Ceannt, James Connolly, and Joseph Plunkett. This version of Amhrn na bhFiann was broadcast each night from 10 to 18 April 1966.

Title: Decorating Easter Eggs with Aonghus McAnally, 1982
Description: In this fun segment from 'How Do You Do' on 'Anything Goes,' Mary Fitzgerald demonstrates how to decorate Easter eggs, providing a step-by-step guide. Co-presenter Aonghus McAnally gets an egg splattered on his forehead in a humorous twist. This episode was broadcast on 3 April 1982.

Title: Exploring the Cork Accent with James N Healy, 1972
Description: Cork actor James N Healy delves into the history and nuances of the Cork accent. He humorously traces its origins from Saint Finbarr to the Danes, Normans, and Huguenots, highlighting the rich vocal cocktail that defines Cork's unique sound. This episode of 'Halls Pictorial Weekly' was broadcast on 21 October 1972.

Title: The Irish Music Scene of 1977
Description: Explore the vibrant Irish music scene of 1977 in this episode of Radharc. Featuring pop star Joe Dolan and rock musician Rory Gallagher, whose song 'Messin With The Kids' inspired the programme title, this episode delves into the impact of pop music on young people. Father Brian DArcy reports from a vinyl pressing plant, discussing the influence of music on the youth of Ireland. With references to ABBA, the Bay City Rollers, and punk rock bands like The Clash and The Sex Pistols, the programme highlights how music shapes lives. Watch Rory Gallagher perform 'Messin with the Kid' at the National Stadium in Dublin and learn about Joe Dolans rise to fame. Broadcast on 25 July 1977, this episode is a testament to the power of music.

Title: Paul OGrady as Lily Savage, Ireland 1995
Description: Join Paul OGrady as his alter ego Lily Savage on The Late Late Show, discussing Mary Robinson, Margaret Thatcher, and Marlene Dietrich. In 1995, Lily Savage participated in a safe sex workshop at Trinity College Dublin, demonstrating the use of condoms with Mary Robinson, a prominent campaigner for contraception. Lily shares her candid opinions on British politicians and recalls her memorable encounter with Marlene Dietrich. Broadcast on 31 March 1995, this episode offers a unique glimpse into the wit and wisdom of Lily Savage, a character beloved by many.

Title: Promoting The Irish Language, 1959
Description: Discover the efforts to promote the Irish language through Gael Linn, an organization founded in 1953. Gael Linn not only organizes language classes and activities but also releases records by major Irish folk and traditional musicians. This 1959 newsreel, part of the 'Amharc ireann' series, features significant events such as the inauguration of amon de Valera as president, currach racing, and Walt Disney's visit to Dublin. Narrated in Irish with English intertitles, this archival footage provides a glimpse into the cultural and linguistic efforts of mid-20th century Ireland.

Title: The First Gaeltacht in Canada, 2007
Description: In 2007, Ontario, Canada, witnessed the inauguration of the first and only Gaeltacht outside of Ireland. This Irish-speaking region, established by Cumann na Gaeltachta, was developed on 60 acres of land purchased in 2006. At the official launch, Irish Ambassador to Canada, Declan Kelly, underscored the significance of this cultural milestone and noted the increasing number of Canadian institutions teaching the Irish language. The project is spearheaded by Aralt Mac Giolla Chainnigh, with plans to host the first Irish language week in July. This RT News report, aired on 18 June 2007, provides comprehensive coverage of the event.

Title: George Boole: The Father of Computer Science, Ireland 1989
Description: In 1989, University College Cork (UCC) honored George Boole, the pioneering mathematician whose work paved the way for modern computer science. This report features a portrait of Boole, an overview of his groundbreaking mathematical theories, and an exhibition at UCC. Professor Des Machale discusses how Boole's untimely death delayed the potential earlier invention of computers. This RT News segment, presented by Tom MacSweeney, delves into Boole's enduring legacy and his monumental contributions to mathematics.

Title: Fiddlers of Sliabh Luachra in Ballyferriter, Co. Kerry, Ireland 1988
Description: In this 1988 episode of 'The Pure Drop,' Sliabh Luachra fiddlers Julia Clifford and Paddy Cronin share captivating stories and play tunes in Ballyferriter, Co. Kerry. Both musicians hail from Gneeveguilla, a region celebrated for its rich tradition of polkas and slides. They recount their musical journeys and join presenter James Kelly in performing reels 'The Mullingar Races' and 'The Heather Breeze.' This episode beautifully highlights the vibrant musical heritage of the Sliabh Luachra area. 'The Pure Drop,' produced by Tony MacMahon, first aired in 1988, showcasing the best of traditional Irish music.

Title: Hippies Embrace Alternative Living in West Cork, Ireland 1986
Description: In 1986, West Cork witnessed an influx of hippies seeking an alternative lifestyle. Among them are Paul and Wanda Margrie, along with their son Benjamin. The family, currently living in a mobile home, plans to build a house on their hillside site. Paul Margrie explains the appeal of West Cork, noting that many people come almost by accident, fall in love with the place, and decide to stay. He acknowledges that local people might think theyre crazy, but they appreciate the slower pace of life and the community's unique charm. This episode of TV GAGA aired on 23 January 1986.

Title: Taxation on Derelict Properties in Cork, Ireland 1984
Description: Cork City Manager Joe McHugh advocates for a tax on derelict properties to encourage their redevelopment. He highlights the issue of property owners using the threat of leaving sites derelict as leverage to gain unreasonable planning permissions. McHugh believes that imposing a tax on these properties would incentivize owners to develop them, thereby reducing the number of eyesores in the city. He also suggests that if taxes are not paid, local authorities should have the power to acquire and sell these sites to interested developers. This policy, McHugh argues, would help preserve older buildings and rejuvenate inner cities. This RT News report was broadcast on 26 April 1984, with Tom MacSweeney reporting.

Title: Dolores ORiordan Talks Life, Music, and More, Ireland 1995
Description:
Dolores ORiordan, the lead singer of The Cranberries, discusses her leg injury, married life, touring, and more. Following the success of their debut album, 'Everybody Else Is Doing It, So Why Cant We?', ORiordan knew their second album would be challenging. 'No Need to Argue', released in late 1994, surpassed expectations and topped charts in Australia, Germany, and Belgium. However, a knee injury led to the sudden cancellation of three homecoming concerts in December 1994. Dolores explains the importance of prioritizing health despite the disappointment it caused fans.

During the interview, ORiordan dispels rumors about cranberry sauce being banned in her home, humorously noting her family's preference for bacon and cabbage. She also shares her joy about marrying Don Burton, Duran Durans tour manager, in 1994 and her plans to build a home in Kerry. Despite her fame, she aims to maintain a normal life when not touring. Her mother, Eileen, proudly confirms that fame hasn't changed her daughter.

The Cranberries are set to resume touring in London and Germany, record an MTV Unplugged show, and play summer festivals with REM. This episode of Kenny Live was broadcast on 16 January 1995, presented by Pat Kenny.

Title: The Kilkenny Witch Trial: Dame Alice Kyteler, Ireland
Description:
In 1324, the bustling city of Kilkenny witnessed Ireland's first witch trial. Dame Alice Kyteler, wealthy and beautiful, drew suspicion due to her four marriages and the mysterious deaths of her husbands. Rumors of a tall dark man visiting her house and the sudden wealth of her son, Robert, fueled the allegations. The Bishop of Ossory, Richard de Ledrede, led the trial against Alice and her maid, Petronella.

A neighbor's testimony about witnessing Alice's strange practices on a May morning played a crucial role in their conviction. Despite the grave charges, Alice remained silent throughout the trial. Both women were sentenced to death, but Alice mysteriously vanished from her cell, leaving only smoke and flame marks behind. Petronella, however, was burned at the stake two weeks later.

This chilling tale is recounted by storyteller Eddie Lenihan in 'Ten Minute Tales', originally broadcast on 21 January 1988.

Title: Sinad OConnor Sings 'Make Me A Channel Of Your Peace', 1993
Description:
Sinad OConnor delivers a poignant a cappella performance of 'Make Me a Channel of Your Peace' on 'The Late Late Show'. The hymn, an adaptation of the 'Prayer of Saint Francis', was composed by Sebastian Temple in 1967. OConnor's performance was part of a fundraiser for the charity Cradle, which aids children and refugees displaced by the Yugoslavian war.

The fundraiser also featured makeovers for five celebrities: Pat OMahony with a grunge look, Michelle Rocca in 1970s attire, Caroline Rothwell as an Italian 1950s starlet, Sinad OConnor transformed into a goddess, and Ronnie Drew as a distinguished gentleman. Despite her dramatic makeover, OConnors heartfelt rendition of the hymn captivated the audience.

This episode of The Late Late Show aired on 26 March 1993, hosted by Gay Byrne.
Tags: Make Me a Channel of Your Peace

Title: Farmers in South Kerry Embrace Yoga, 2018
Description:
In South Kerry, farmers are turning to yoga to enhance their physical and mental well-being. These all-mens yoga sessions help combat rural isolation, increase body awareness, and correct imbalances. Yoga Instructor Lesley MacVean highlights the benefits, explaining how yoga alleviates stress and improves suppleness. Farmer Mike OShea appreciates the social aspect of the weekly classes and finds them more beneficial than pub socializing. He notes the physical benefits, particularly for his knees and back, and describes feeling rejuvenated after each session. This RT News report was broadcast on 26 February 2018, with Sen Mac an tSthigh reporting.

Title: Hamilton Harty's 'With The Wild Geese' Performed by RT Symphony Orchestra, 1980
Description:
The RT Symphony Orchestra performs 'With The Wild Geese,' a piece composed by Hamilton Harty in 1910. Harty, hailing from County Down, was a distinguished accompanist, composer, and conductor. This performance, led by Alan Smale and conducted by Colman Pearce, showcases the orchestra's talent. The episode of Insight RT Symphony Concert Orchestra was first broadcast on 19 February 1980.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Comparing Irish and Japanese Workers at Sony, 1963
Description:
Mr. Suzuki, a manager at the Sony plant in Shannon, Co. Clare, discusses the differences between Irish and Japanese workers. He observes that Irish workers often leave after training, while Japanese workers show greater loyalty to their company. Suzuki highlights differences in attitudes towards waste and supervision, noting that Irish supervisors are gentler compared to their Japanese counterparts. Despite these differences, Suzuki believes that with more investment, Irish workers can become excellent employees. This episode of Broadsheet was broadcast on 30 August 1963, with John ODonoghue reporting.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Sliabh Luachra's Musical Heritage, Co. Kerry, 1981
Description:
Johnny OLeary shares insights on the unique music of Sliabh Luachra and the legendary fiddle player and teacher Pdraig OKeeffe, who defined the local style. Sliabh Luachra, 'The Mountain of the Rushes,' located in east Kerry, is known for its distinct musical style characterized by lively slides and polkas. Twice a week, locals gather at Dan Connells pub in Knocknagree to dance and play traditional music. Johnny OLeary, a self-taught accordion player, became proficient under the guidance of Pdraig OKeeffe, who used his own notation system to teach music. This episode of Hand Me Down was broadcast on 4 May 1981, with Doireann N Bhriain reporting.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Gallagher's Bakery Success in London, 1995
Description:
Gallaghers Bakery in Ardara, County Donegal, founded by Frank Gallagher in 1968, has become a success story by appealing to the tastes of Londons elite. Operating from a state-of-the-art facility, the bakery produces over 150 types of breads, cakes, and confections. Their award-winning white soda bread is popular across Ireland and has gained a foothold in Harrods, London. Managing director Frank Gallagher expresses pride in this achievement. Plans are in place to expand into the French market. This episode of Nationwide was broadcast on 6 July 1995, with Eileen Magnier reporting.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Electric Guitar Exhibition at National Museum of Ireland, 2006
Description:
Celebrating 75 years of the electric guitar, the 'RockChic' exhibition at the National Museum of Ireland features over 100 guitars played by legends like Jimi Hendrix, Phil Lynott, Marc Bolan, and Van Morrison. A special collection includes guitars owned by Irish electric guitar pioneer Rory Gallagher. The highlight is the 'Frying Pan' guitar, the world's first electric guitar made in 1931. Rory Gallaghers 1961 Fender Stratocaster, described as 'his pride and joy' by his brother Donal, is also showcased. This RT News report was broadcast on 23 November 2006, with Paddy McKenna reporting.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Exploring Atheism and Agnosticism in Ireland, 1994
Description:
In this episode of 'Would You Believe?', the focus is on atheism and agnosticism, exploring the growing acceptance of non-believers in Ireland. Reporter Gemma MacCrohan meets individuals who have opted out of the religions they were born into, including a baby being raised in a non-religious home. Interviews with a humanist, a Catholic, and a non-believer provide insights into their beliefs and the future for non-religious families in Ireland. This episode of Would You Believe?: Free Spirit aired on 20 January 1994.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Family Concerns in Ireland, 1992
Description:
In this episode of 'Family Matters', Brigie de Courcy explores a wide range of issues that concern Irish families. On Grafton Street in Dublin, she gathers an A-Z list of topics from passersby, covering everything from adoption and babysitting to xenophobia and zoos. The programme highlights the diverse concerns of family members and sets the stage for topics to be covered in the series. This episode of 'Family Matters' first aired on 7 October 1992.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: From Hairdresser to Sculptor: Seamus Furlong's Journey, 1987
Description:
Seamus Furlong, a well-known hairdresser in New Ross, County Wexford, has pursued his passion for sculpting in retirement. After years of balancing his career with his artistic aspirations, Seamus now dedicates himself to creating bronze sculptures. His first full-scale exhibition includes works such as Dr. Tom Walshe and Wexford hurler Nicky Rackard. Despite the financial risk, Seamus's work is gaining recognition and selling well. This RT News report by Michael Ryan was broadcast on 20 January 1987.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: A House Rocks Lunchtime at Virgin Megastore, Dublin 1987
Description:
During a free lunchtime gig at the Virgin Megastore on Dublins Aston Quay, A House performs their third single Heart Happy. The Dublin band, consisting of Dave Couse, Fergal Bunbury, Dermot Wylie, and Martin Healy, attracts a dedicated crowd. Fans and other musicians share their thoughts on the appeal of lunchtime gigs. This episode of Borderline aired on 1 December 1987.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Schoolboys Build Innovative Car in Co. Antrim, 1982
Description:
Six students from Rathcoole High School in Newtownabbey, County Antrim, have designed and built their own two-seater sports car. The distinctive banana-shaped vehicle, equipped with a Toyota Corolla engine and fiberglass body, is set to compete in the Build A Car competition in England. Teacher Raymond Cauldwell highlights the educational value of the project. This RT News report was broadcast on 27 September 1982.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Stone Carving and Spirituality in Early Medieval Ireland, 1982
Description:
The high crosses of Ireland, dating from the ninth century, serve as central features of monasteries and are adorned with biblical scenes. This episode of Radharc: The Celtic Monastery explores the significance of these ornately carved crosses, with insights into their historical and religious importance. Narrated by Cyril Cusack, the program aired on 22 February 1982.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Irish Dancing Champions 1993
Description:
Dancers from the Wogan School of Irish Dancing perform on Live At Three in celebration of Saint Patricks Day. Led by World Champion dancer Maria Wogan, the school boasts numerous accolades including the All-Ireland and American National Championships. The dancers showcase treble reels, a hornpipe, and the traditional set dance jig Saint Patricks Day. This episode aired on 12 March 1993.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Irish Language Lessons 1968
Description:
This episode of Bunts Cainte teaches the use of the word anonn meaning over to, along with the song Henry My Son and a tale about a rabbit that ends up as dinner. Seamus g  Tuama and Ruth Buchanan guide viewers through practical examples and translations, with illustrations demonstrating the word in context. The program encourages viewers to repeat sentences to practice pronunciation. This episode aired on 24 October 1968.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: Kilmalkedar Church 1980
Description:
Historian Ted Creedon guides Donncha  Dlaing through the early Christian site of Kilmalkedar Church on the Dingle peninsula. The site, dating back to the 5th century, features a 12th-century church built with corbelling technique, a 7th-century sandstone cross, a sundial, and an Ogham stone believed to have curative powers. Ted Creedon shares the historical significance and architectural features of this remarkable site. This episode of Donnchas Travelling Roadshow aired on 22 March 1980.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: The Book Of Kells Explained 1989
Description:
The Book of Kells, over 1200 years old, is housed in the Berkeley Library at Trinity College Dublin. Jo-Maxi gives viewers a chance to win a limited edition copy of the Book of Kells for their school by submitting artwork related to the book. Reproducing the book involved photographing every page, with each copy weighing 20lbs and retailing for approximately $14,800 or 10,000. This episode aired on 11 December 1989.

Copyright: Content presented is sourced from RT Archives. All rights are owned by RT, and the content is used here for educational and informational purposes only.

Title: United Ireland Poll Results 1973
Description:
An opinion poll conducted by Irish Marketing Surveys and published in The Sunday Independent found that 37% of those surveyed in the Republic of Ireland do not see a united Ireland happening at the moment. Richie Ryan TD discusses the interpretation of the poll and its implications, while Paddy Devlin of the SDLP comments on the relevance of the forthcoming referendum in Northern Ireland. This episode aired on 4 March 1973.

The program, presented by John ODonovan, includes interviews with James Robert Emmet, the great-great-grand-nephew of Robert Emmet, and features a voice-over by Niall Tibn. This episode aired on 23 February 1970.

Liam OFlynn, a founder of Planxty, has collaborated with a variety of artists including Kate Bush and Mark Knopfler. Leo Rowsomes teachings and craftsmanship have left a lasting impact on the world of Irish traditional music. This episode of The Pure Drop aired on 20 September 1991.

Title: Exploring the Paranormal 1992
Description:

Leslie Shepard, editor of the Encyclopedia of Occultism and Parapsychology, discusses humanitys fascination with the occult and its implications. Shepard suggests that while interest in the occult can be a form of exerting power over others, it also pushes the boundaries of conventional thinking. This episode aired on 29 October 1992.

Title: The Tragic Tale of Bridget Cleary 1983
Description:
The 1893 murder of Bridget Cleary by her husband, who believed she was a witch or possessed by a fairy changeling, is explored in this episode of The Late Late Show. Joe Ambroses novel Loves Dark Light and The Hosts concept album Tryal draw inspiration from this tragic event. Eamon Carr, a member of The Host, discusses the gruesome nature of the story and its continued relevance in highlighting violence and superstition in Irish society. This episode aired on 17 December 1983.

Title: Vietnamese Refugees in Ireland, 2004
Description:
In 1979, Ireland welcomed 212 Vietnamese boat people fleeing the communist regime. On the 25th anniversary of their arrival, the program Mono explores their journey and experiences. Reporter Shalini Sinha interviews Pham Van Tuyen, who shares his story of arriving in Ireland as a twelve-year-old and reflects on the changes since then. Initially housed in Blanchardstown Hospital and Swords, Co. Dublin, refugees were later dispersed across the country, with Tuyen and his uncle settling in Midleton, Co. Cork. This episode aired on 7 April 2004.

Title: Rolling Stones at Slane Castle, 2007

Guitarist Ronnie Wood shared his excitement about playing at Slane again, noting the significance of the 25-year gap. The band is rumored to earn 2 million euros from the gig. This RT News report aired on 18 August 2007.

Title: Irish Astronaut Search, 1991
Description:
In 1991, the search for an Irish astronaut to join the European Space Agency's first manned space mission begins. CEO of Eolas, Jim McBride, discusses the rigorous application and selection process with Pat Kenny. From over four hundred applicants, four finalists remain: Dr. Ciaran Bolger, Dr. Deirdre McMahon, Captain William Butler, and Captain Kevin Barry. They share their experiences and motivations, including their reactions to challenging tests, especially the motion sickness test. This episode of 'Kenny Live' was broadcast on 25 May 1991.

Title: Irish Archaeological Heritage, 1967
Description:
This 1967 documentary explores Ireland's rich archaeological heritage, detailing excavation methods, artefact dating, and the importance of museums. The soil of Ireland preserves a vast record of human history, from Newgrange to various habitation and burial sites. The program explains the significance of the National Monuments Act (1930) and the Three Ages System - The Stone Age, The Bronze Age, and The Iron Age, established by Danish archaeologist Christian Jrgensen Thomsen. This episode of 'Heritage' was broadcast on 17 May 1967 and was presented by Andy OMahony.

Title: Cold Weather Problems, 2010

In 2010, freezing weather in Ireland causes legal issues, water shortages, and public attention for a man who slips on an icy Dublin footpath. Dublin City Council works to clear and grit roads and pavements, while personal injury lawyer Liam Moloney discusses the potential rise in personal injury claims. Residents express concerns about legal liability if someone falls on cleared paths. Additionally, the cold weather causes burst water mains, leading to critical water shortages and warnings of potential cut-offs from Dublin City Council and Fingal County Council. This RT News report was broadcast on 8 January 2010.

Parents and medical specialists call for regulation. The family of Colm Hodkinson, who died after using head shop drugs, share their story. Title: The Decline of the Irish Economy - 1975
Description:
This report examines the severe decline in the Irish economy during the 1970s. Michael Ryan discusses the rise in unemployment, the decline in traditional jobs due to competition from the EEC, and the fall in new industries and investment. Irish exports are down 7%, inflation is at 23.9%, and the national debt stands at 2.7 billion. The report highlights the difficulties faced by the economy and the bleak outlook for the future.

This 7 Days report was broadcast on 16 December 1975. The presenters are Michael Ryan and John ODonoghue.

Title: Winter Freeze Relief Efforts - Ireland 1982
Description:
With road and rail routes still blocked after heavy snow, the Air Corps assist those cut off. Six Air Corps helicopters flew twenty-seven ambulance missions and eleven food drops. More food drops are planned, including for the village of Newcastle in County Dublin, which has been cut off for days. However, the Army press office has issued a statement saying that they have no supplies of bread or milk. People in difficulty or in need of essential food supplies should contact their local Garda station. The helicopters are also being used to assist the ESB in restoring electrical power. The Automobile Association (AA) has warned that most roads throughout the country are still in dangerous condition. While many roads have reopened, there are fears that freezing temperatures will again make them impassable. The AA advises drivers to stay off the roads.

An RT News report broadcast on 10 January 1982. The reporter is Andrew Kelly.

Title: Military Exercise in Sligo - 1977
Description:
The brigade of the Southern Command is deployed in Sligo for a military exercise to prepare for an attack on Ireland. The Southern Command is the Irish armys strategic reserve, held back at the early stages of a conventional battle. They are only called into action when a decisive strike is needed. In Sligo, men from Corks 4th Infantry Battalion, Limericks 12th Battalion, and other reserve units carried out an exercise in the Ox Mountains. Fighter jets, spotter planes, and helicopters provided vital firepower. The drill tested the soldiers in the event of an attack on Ireland.

An RT News report broadcast on 8 September 1977. The reporter is Jim Fahy.

Title: Snow Disruptions Across Ireland - 1982
Description:
The heaviest snowfall across Ireland for decades results in traffic chaos, fuel and food shortages, and the closure of schools and workplaces. Transport, communications, and electricity supplies were badly disrupted in the worst cold spell since 1963. Brendan OBrien reports on how the severe weather conditions are impacting towns along the east coast, with emergency services having huge demands placed upon them. Five helicopters from the Army Air Corps made more than twenty mercy missions from Baldonnel Aerodrome. One of the most frequent emergency calls involved pregnant women in labor. Almost 24 hours after the first snowfall, many people are having to fend for themselves, digging a way out of snow drifts and clearing roads. Up to 50 people are still stuck at the Aeromotive factory in Dublin. The Naas Road has come to a standstill as people attempt to dig themselves out of the snow drifts. Train stations and airports have also been forced to close, with 400 people having to spend the night at Heuston Station, trapped as a result of frozen railway points. The Dublin airport road was effectively impassable in places, as were most main roads in and out of the capital. Many small towns on the east coast are almost cut off from food supplies, with people now queuing for limited supplies of bread. Around 55,000 homes, mainly in rural areas, were without electricity today. The ESB is working tirelessly to return services, with about 25,000 homes in isolated areas remaining blacked out.

An RT News report broadcast on 9 January 1982. The reporter is Brendan OBrien.

Title: Did the Romans Settle in Ireland? - 1996
Description:
Historians say the Romans never settled in Ireland, but could evidence from a site in north Dublin suggest otherwise? The Drumanagh headland in north County Dublin, just across the bay from Loughshinny harbour, is easily identifiable by its nineteenth-century Martello tower. Archaeologist and local resident Dr. Peter Harbison explains that evidence of an empire from much further in time was discovered in 1947, and other artefacts from the site exist which are Roman in character and which suggest a settlement of people from Roman Britain. Harbison believes that legal difficulties are the main reasons standing in the way of a full-scale archaeological dig that could provide answers to many questions about the Drumanagh promontory. The headland is frequented by locals exercising and walking their dogs, and they want to see it protected, says local historian Declan Stack.

An RT News broadcast on 22 January 1996. The reporter is Alasdair Jackson.

Title: Supernatural Butter Stealing: The Dead Hand Legend, Ireland 1970

Title: 10,000 Miles in a Supervan: European Road Trip, 1972
Description:
In 1972, a 1960 Ford Anglia van was transformed from a banger into a 'Supervan' and taken on an epic 10,000-mile journey across 12 European countries. Title: Challenges of Rural Life in Ballycroy, Co. Mayo (1975)
Description:
In 1975, Ballycroy in Co. Mayo faced significant challenges such as emigration, school closures, poor land, and lack of electricity. The '7 Days' programme visits this rural area, where intermittent farming is often the only means of income. The remaining population feels forgotten, as many young people leave for better opportunities abroad.

The programme captures the bittersweet moments of a wedding at Keenagh church, where the newlyweds return to England after their ceremony. Local schools have had to amalgamate due to dwindling student numbers, and children now travel longer distances to attend classes.

The Kilroy family discusses the difficulties of living without electricity and the challenges of getting their daughter Mary to school. This report, broadcast on 4 November 1975, was presented by John O'Donoghue.

This 1991 report explores how country music has evolved in Ireland, featuring insights from musicians, managers, record shop owners, and fans. Niall Toner opens the segment with a rendition of 'Lost Highway' by Leon Payne, a song popularized by Hank Williams.

Country music in Ireland spans a wide range of styles and has become a staple at karaoke nights and in record shops across the country. Record shop owners Padraig Whelan and Declan Loughman discuss the genre's place in the Irish music scene. Artist Declan Nerney talks about how his act builds on the show band tradition, blending various musical styles to appeal to a broad audience.

This episode of 'Changing Places: Country Roads' was broadcast on 4 December 1991.

Title: What Irish Kids Watched on TV (1989)
Description:
In 1989, 'Down the Tube' asked Irish children about their favorite and least favorite TV shows. With all viewing done through a traditional television set, kids shared their thoughts on popular programs of the time, including Dallas, Zig and Zag, Hulk Hogan, Neighbours, Coronation Street, The A-Team, MacGyver, and more.

'Down the Tube' was a television series about TV, where presenter Marian Finucane and a panel of guests reflected on the week's programming. This particular episode was broadcast on 16 January 1989.

Title: John B. Keane and the Weather-Predicting Dog (1974)
Description:
From his pub in Co. Kerry, playwright John B. Keane talks to Halls Pictorial Weeklys Frank Hall about a local dog who he claims is better at predicting the weather than anyone at RT. According to Keane, the dog crosses the road when it is going to rain and returns when it stops. Keane also humorously accuses RT weatherman Seamus Miller of kidnapping the dog.

This episode of Halls Pictorial Weekly was broadcast on 24 January 1974.

Title: Prince Charles Visits Dublin City (1995)
Description:
On his first official visit to the Republic of Ireland, Prince Charles receives a warm welcome from Dubliners, including a memorable kiss from one admirer.

Prince Charles's visit marks the first official visit by a member of the British royal family since Irish independence. As he leaves the British Tourist Authority office on Dame Street, he is greeted by crowds along College Green and Trinity College Dublin (TCD).

However, the visit is not without incident as protesters throw eggs, two of which hit the Princes car, while another narrowly misses him. Garda arrest three men in connection with the incident.

At TCD, Prince Charles is welcomed by Trinity Chancellor Frank OReilly and Provost Thomas Mitchell. He signs the visitors' book and receives a private viewing of the Book of Kells. Later, during a walkabout, he chats with the crowd, including 63-year-old Bernie Fitzgerald from Kilbarrack, who asks the Prince for a kiss, to which he obliges.

The Prince also visits St Andrews Resource Centre on Pearse Street, where he spends time with staff, locals, and representatives from various community organizations. He gets his first taste of Guinness and receives a portrait from three-year-old Gemma Murphy.

The 1995 visit by Prince Charles is seen as paving the way for Queen Elizabeth II's visit to Ireland in 2011.

This RT News report, presented by Michael OKane, was broadcast on 1 June 1995.

Title: A Mayo Man Returns Home (1975)
Description:
Joe Malone, originally from Breaffy, County Mayo, returns to his childhood home after 26 years in America. After a successful career in the travel industry, including time with Brd Filte, Malone revisits his roots in this episode of RT's 'My Own Place'.

Malone reminisces about the Brownes of Breaffy House, the tall trees, and the high walls that kept children out of the estate grounds. Today, the big house is a hotel, and Malones old schoolteacher, Andy McTeigue, shares stories about the last of the Brownes.

My Own Place: Joe Malones Mayo was broadcast on 15 October 1975.

Title: Irish Men Who Built Nuclear Power Stations (1965)
Description:
This 'Radharc' film explores the lives of Irish men working on the construction of a nuclear power plant at Oldbury, Bristol, England in 1965. Living in a purpose-built camp away from the nearest towns, these men share their experiences of working in such a challenging environment.

The film includes interviews with Irish workers discussing their living conditions, pay, and the loneliness of being away from home. Father Peter Lemass, who reports on the site, emphasizes the importance of the workers' well-being, as employers must provide food, accommodation, and recreational facilities.

The film portrays the men as nomadic workers who long to return to Ireland, though many end up staying in England longer than planned. The report highlights the difficulties of maintaining family ties and the struggle to find a sense of belonging.

Title: Irish Dancing Championships (1964)
Description:
Young dancers from across Ireland gather at the Mansion House in Dublin to compete in the 1964 Oireachtas Na Rince, the All-Ireland Irish Dancing Championships. The competition, organized by An Coimisin Le Rinc Gaelacha, features both solo and cil dancing, with nearly 1,000 entries representing almost every county in Ireland, as well as contingents from London, Manchester, and Liverpool.

This RT News report captures the excitement and dedication of these young competitors as they showcase their skills in jigs, reels, and other traditional dances.

The report was broadcast on 7 March 1964.
